headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Q3 call this morning. As always, thanks for the interest in the company. Steve Malcolm, our President and CEO, is going to review a few slides that we have prepared for this morning, but be aware t
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Q3 call this morning. As always, thanks for the interest in the company. Steve Malcolm, our President and CEO, is going to review a few slides that we have prepared for this morning, but be aware though, as always, all of our business unit heads - Alan Armstrong, Ralph Hill, Phil Wright - as well as Don Chappel, the CFO, are here in the room ready for questions that weâll take after Steveâs remarks.
This morning on our website, Williams.com, you should be able to find the slides, the data book, the press release which were all issued this morning. The Q3 10Q will also be available today and youâll be able to access that on the website as well. At the beginning of the slide deck are the forward-looking statements and the disclaimer on oil and gas reserves. Those are both very important and integral to the remarks, so you should review those. Also there are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to generally accepted accounting principles. Those schedules are available and they follow the presentation.
So with that Iâll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Travis. Welcome to our Q3 earnings call and thanks for your interest in our company. Letâs just dive into the slides.Slide 5 shows the key financial results. Of course adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations is $0.22 for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Travis. Welcome to our Q3 earnings call and thanks for your interest in our company. Letâs just dive into the slides.
Slide 5 shows the key financial results. Of course adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations is $0.22 for the Q3; year to date of $0.86 is 28% higher than 2009. Our 2010 through â12 earnings guidance is relatively unchanged. Weâll go into some of the tweaks that weâve made here a little later. And we did record a $1.7 billion non cash impairment due to the recent decline in natural gas prices.
Slide 6 please. Some of the major highlights from the quarter. We did reach agreement to sell our Piceance Basin gathering and processing assets to WPZ. I have a slide later that goes into more detail on that transaction.
Secondly, weâre very excited about the progress that weâre making to grow out businesses in the Marcellus Shale, and let me just offer some color on that. In the E&P space, weâre now operating three rigs. That number will be increasing to six by the Q4 of 2011. Current returns are greater than 30%. We have seen and expect significant continued improvements as Williams becomes operator and as we proceed with the large Susquehanna drilling program. As you know, we now have 100,000 net acres at an average cost of less than $7000 an acre, gross production near 20 million a day at the end of the Q3 and the Westmoreland County Slavic Trust wells have been the best performing to date.
As well, good growth in the mid-stream space. Weâre rapidly expanding the Laurel Mountain mid-stream gathering system. Projects there will ultimately provide over 1.5 Bcf a day of gathering capacity, and 1400 miles of gathering lines including 400 new miles of large diameter pipe. As well construction has begun on our Shamrock Compressor Station, where weâll have an initial capacity of 60 million a day, but is expandable to 350 million a day. And that Shamrock Station will likely be the largest central delivery point out of the Laurel Mountains System.
As well we have the Springville System and we now have all of the right of way. We expect to begin construction in the Q1 of 2011, in service in 2011. And given the demand from customers weâve upped the project size from a 20-inch to a 24-inch diameter pipeline. So a lot of really exciting things going on in the Marcellus.
Moving back now to talk a little bit more about the highlights on the slide. We did close and finance the Overland Pass pipeline transaction, and there was strong demand for the WPZ share offering. We did complete the restructuring transaction with the PZMZ merger. Weâre prepared for a November startup of Sundance Trail. We brought the new Echo Springs TXP4 into full operation at the end of the Q3. And just to remind you, the TXP4 plant adds about 350 million a day of processing and 30,000 barrels per day of natural gas liquids production and capacity, roughly doubling what we already had there at Echo Springs.
We increased the WPZ distribution by 1.5? and did announce as you well know the leadership secession plan effective January, 2011, which has Alan coming on board as President & CEO.
Slide 7 please. This slide just gives the guidance range and midpoints for Henry Hub and Rockies net gas prices, crude oil, and NGL margins and our assumed NGL to crude oil relationship. I think there are just two points I want to make here: one, these are unchanged from the commodity price assumptions that we gave you at Barclays; and I guess the second point is yes, we have seen natural gas prices fall since then but weâve run the numbers. And if you used strip prices you would really see the minimalist impact on our earnings per share for â11 and â12.
Slide 8 please. Steady growth even on expected low nat gas prices. This shows adjusted EPS, adjusted segment profit, cash flow from operations and capital. And just the key points here: earnings per share reflects some tightening of ranges in â11 and â12. Segment profit reflects tightening in â11 and a slight increase in the range in â12. CFFO tightens the range consistent with earnings. 2011 CAPEX, weâre seeing some carryover from 2010; as well as PZ, with its Laurel Mountains and Piceance growth, thatâs added a little capital. 2012 capital as well is up a little bit as a result of Laurel Mountains and Piceance growth.
Slide 9. Again, segment profit moving up even during a low nat gas price environment. Thatâs good stuff.
Slide 10, please. This is the slide that we have been showing the last couple of years, which shows the maintenance cap, the maintenance to maintain volumes, the growth projects by year and divided out by WPZ, E&P, and other.
A couple points here: youâll note in 2010, the blue WPZ growth bar is a little larger, and thatâs obviously associated with the bar gas transaction, the Piceance gathering and processing transaction that I spoke about earlier. As well youâll notice the growth capital, the yellow bar in â10 and â11 and â12 continues to grow quite nicely. Of course that includes that yellow bar, the other category includes Canada where, due to our first mover technological advantage we continue to anticipate making significant, attractive investments over the next three years.
Slide 11. This is our familiar pie chart for WPZ midstream, and as you well know weâve had success in moving projects. Due to our success from the left to the right we really see huge growth opportunities in the Marcellus, opportunities out west to expand on our already significant position out there, and weâre still excited about what the Gulf offers.
Slide 12, please. The WPZ gas pipeline, inventory of projects - $1.3 billion represented here. PZ franchise, or the gas pipeline franchise is a major segment of the nationâs energy infrastructure, transporting 12% of the countryâs gas on any given day. And our gas pipeline enterprise produces consistent low risks of substantial free cash flow.
You know, weâve talked about the base hit approach that weâve used here. Most of our growth has been and will continue to be from market whole projects within our exiting footprint, as opposed to in my view the more risky producer-push pipes which are dependent on a given supply basin. I would say looking out into the future thereâs a significant opportunity for expansions to serve power generation, particularly in the Southeast US.
Slide 13, please. I think youâre familiar with our Premier E&P portfolio, and we have talked in the past that the Marcellus will soon become our second largest producing basin. A couple other key points: our drilling returns remain strong and our major operating areas of the Piceance, Marcellus, and Powder River with returns ranging from 17% to near 40% - even in this low nat gas price environment. A major reason for this is our industry leadership position on low costs. And I think a great example here is in the Piceance for 2010 weâve improved our well costs by 3% to 6% versus 2009.
We have a unique industry portfolio that allows us to flex up our drilling program, up or down, without losing value or losing leases. And as discussed in our September guidance update we decreased our rig counts for 2011 by nine rigs and 2012 by 17 rigs from our previous guidance, and simply put we can do that and yet preserve our value and leases while we wait for gas prices to improve. And we still expect to grow our production by 3% in 2011, 7% in 2012.
Slide 14. This is the drop down slide, so this is a large scale asset and you see the bullet points on the left there: 150 miles of large diameter pipe connects to 3300 wells, six aiming and treating facilities, 160,000 horsepower of compression, 1.2 Bcf a day of dew point processing capacity. These are significant assets. The attractive financial profile and some of the key points there: $105 million of WPZ segment profit in DD&A in 2011, immediately accretive to DCF for PZ. And as the general partner, Williams will receive a favored distribution increase. WPZ is acquiring fee business, thatâs good stuff. Williamsâ E&P segment retains liquids upside and we have a life of lease dedication from Williams E&P. And we expect closing to occur in November of 2010.
We still get a lot of questions and thereâs a lot of dialog in the industry about whatâs going to happen with NGLs and ethane and ethylene, and Iâm certainly not going to read all of these bullet points but there are some points I want to make. And weâve made these in the past and continue to believe in them. Short-term the fundamentals remain very strong for near-term ethane demand, as ethane is maintaining its favorable position in being the low cost feedstock for ethylene production. A lot of people are worried about the shale plays and the large supplies of ethane that are going to come on, but you have to remember - large supplies of ethane from the shale plays will require significant infrastructure and infrastructure takes time. The very strong ethylene markets will incent plants to invest in small plant expansions and WMB, Williams, has a low cost expansion investment ongoing at Geismar which is going to increase our capacity by 12%.
Longer-term, clearly the US right now holds a large advantage for being the next low cost traunch for ethylene production given the abundant natural gas supplies. The US should be in a strong position to export its ethylene derivative products at a lower cost than incremental production elsewhere in the world. And I think ultimately the big question is will ethylene capacity be expanded to keep pace with increased NGL supplies here in the US? And given the high ethane to ethylene spreads that exist, we think ultimately that conversions and low cost capacity increases will happen.
Slide 16 and 17 talk about the progress we have made for 2010 priorities for value creation, and you can see more and more of the boxes now have checkmarks. And so weâre pleased with the progress that weâre making there.
Slide 18, please. The âWhy Williams is a Winning Investment,â no change here. We think that we have the assets, the people. We have proven that we can execute crisply around our strategies. We are committed to financial discipline and believe that weâre going to have very, very attractive results in the future.
Before we go to Q&A Iâve got a few comments and Alan will as well, but I wanted to address questions about my decision to retire. Thereâs no hidden intrigue or back story here. As Gwen and I were thinking about the next chapter in our life, and having been with Williams for 26 years, nine of those as CEO, we decided that again, started talking about it over the summer and ultimately decided that it made sense for us to retire at the end of 2010. And as you know, the requirements are such that once you make your final decision you need to make it public in four or five days. So itâs a decision that weâre very excited about.
But the board was well prepared for this decision. Weâve had an active and comprehensive secession planning process in place. The board and I are confident in the team and confident in Alan Armstrong, and believe that Alan will take the company to new heights. Iâve had the great opportunity to work with Alan, not only in his role as heading up our midstream group but Iâve worked closely with him back in the 1990s when I was running midstream.
And I donât want to get too carried away here, but the experience and culture here at Williams is very unique and Iâve been proud to work here for the past 26 years. I truly believe the Williams experience, the Williams culture is a competitive advantage for us. So with that Iâll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. First of all, Steve, I want to make sure that we acknowledge the accomplishments that Steve brought forward. If you think back to the very difficult and tenuous circumstances that Steve was handed, and to where heâs brought us to today with a ver
componenttext:
Great. First of all, Steve, I want to make sure that we acknowledge the accomplishments that Steve brought forward. If you think back to the very difficult and tenuous circumstances that Steve was handed, and to where heâs brought us to today with a very strong, very stable company with tremendous potential to create shareholder value from where we sit today- We have that potential in terms of financial resources. Weâve got extremely well positioned assets in the markets they serve, and weâve got tremendous organizational capabilities in terms of exploiting resource plays, both in our E&P group and in our midstream group. And our pipes are well positioned to serve the change in the markets today thatâs associated with the resource plays.
And certainly as Steve mentioned, our culture with one of the most passionate and committed workforces in the business today, leaves me with a tremendous amount of optimism about where we can take this. And I just want to say a big thanks to Steve for giving us such a tremendous platform to take the company from today.
So we are in a very enviable position. Weâve got all the tools necessary to really accelerate shareholder value. Weâre going to be reviewing all alternatives and Iâm charged up and can assure you that with the great platform, the well positioned assets, and organizational capabilities that we have today, we will not be sitting still. I donât have any particular bias other than to assure ourselves that we are creating the most shareholder value that is enduring and allows our businesses to be the most successful they can be for the benefit of our investors.
  And with that I will turn this over to Q&A.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the goodwill impairment and the impairment of primarily the Barnett area really is an accounting exercise that we work on, and itâs basically thereâs several models there. Itâs the fair value model, and gross cash flows are discounted against
componenttext:
Well, the goodwill impairment and the impairment of primarily the Barnett area really is an accounting exercise that we work on, and itâs basically thereâs several models there. Itâs the fair value model, and gross cash flows are discounted against that. So as we look at that for example on the goodwill, the internal fair value was slightly less than the carrying value, and in that case it caused an impairment in our goodwill which was, the goodwill for us was associated with a 2001, almost a decade ago acquisition of Barrett. And it wasnât cash out the door; it was really a deferred tax liability gross up if you will. And that became our goodwill, and over the course of the last decade as we looked at prices and all that, we really didnât have any opportunities for impairment. And then with the poor price curve itâs gone down greater than 22% since the beginning of the year. That caused us to look at that and that caused that write down.
For the Barnett it was simply just a factor of the fair value again versus the carrying value. Our Ford prices have come down substantially and we have that impairment. That really doesnât have anything to do with go forward on where weâre headed primarily in the Piceance and the Marcellus, where most of our draw is, and a lesser extension, the Powder. So those are just accounting exercises. You look at it, you understand the value of what youâre carrying versus the value of the fair value, and those are impaired from there.
And I donât know if your last question is more about the industry or us. We know that the level of rigs, which we did drop a substantial amount of rigs in our forecast at the Barclays conference for â11 and â12, but we know that we believe our production wasnât growing that much. I think the industry in general hopefully at some time weâll see our competitors put on more of a return hat and finish drilling for holding leases, and finish drilling for holding JVs and weâll see a more rational response to the gas prices. And therefore, at that point I would expect you would see some of the gas supply to decline.

componenttext: It is based on, really what happened is the strips through 2025 is down about, as I mentioned, greater than 20%. And I would say at this point I would not trend towards the lower part. We feel confident that our drilling program, as I think Steve mentioned, our returns in the areas weâre drilling are going to be anywhere from 17% to near 40%. We have cut our drilling program substantially but at this point we feel that weâll beâ¦ We donât give out the exact but we give a pretty wide range, and I think most of you guys look at the middle part of that range and thatâs kind of what you assume, and thatâs generally where we try to come out. If prices would continue to come down substantially we always have the ability as Steve said to flex our portfolio down, our drilling program down, and to respond accordingly until prices come the right way.

Craig, this is Don. I might just comment - you have to remember that Williams retains its GP interest, and with that we get a substantial, you could call it a royalty but we get a substantial profit participation in that asset despite the fact we dropped it down. So I think when you look at the GP interest on top of what we actually sold it for in terms of cash, I think you get a much higher valuation.
In terms of whatâs left to drop down, you know, we have a 25.5% interest in Gullstream, which is eligible beginning late Q1. Thatâs not guidance in terms of what we may do but it would be eligible for drop down kind of late Q1, and beyond that we really havenât earmarked any other assets.

componenttext: Thank you. Recently a couple of your competitors have decided to dance and leave you guys out of it, creating some new projects in the Marcellus and the Eagleford. Does this signal a change in how you would pursue the McMullen lateral expansion in the Eagleford and the Keystone Connector in the Marcellus?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Phil Wright, let me tackle the Keystone Connector. It doesnât change anything with respect to what weâre pursuing on that project and we continue to work with producers. As you know, the difficulty in achieving success on any of those large in
componenttext:
This is Phil Wright, let me tackle the Keystone Connector. It doesnât change anything with respect to what weâre pursuing on that project and we continue to work with producers. As you know, the difficulty in achieving success on any of those large infrastructure projects is getting producers to a position where they have a clear enough vision of what their needs are going to be and what market they want to try to serve sufficient to sign a precedent agreement that would produce enough security around a project that would have an investment profile attractive enough to proceed. And I think that chicken and egg problem persists.
With respect to the McMullen Lateral. I know Alan will have some thoughts probably from the midstream perspective, but from the pipeline perspective I can tell you that as more drilling is done out there and as the lenses of liquids-rich and oil-rich finds sort of move northward, weâre seeing a higher level of interest in dry gas but nonetheless a very high level of interest in the McMullen Lateral.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All I would add to that in terms of the, first of all in terms of the Marcellus is we have a tremendous joint venture in our Atlas joint venture with Atlas, Laurel Mountain. Outstanding growth alternatives coming out of that and weâve got some exiting d
componenttext:
All I would add to that in terms of the, first of all in terms of the Marcellus is we have a tremendous joint venture in our Atlas joint venture with Atlas, Laurel Mountain. Outstanding growth alternatives coming out of that and weâve got some exiting developments going on on the north end of our Springville Lateral. And so I donât feel like weâre being left out in any way, shape or form. In fact I would tell you we probably have one of the strongest JVs in the Marcellus from a midstream perspective in terms of creating shareholder value going up there. So Iâm very excited about that position.
In terms of the Eagleford, the Markham plant, which is primarily positioned to serve the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, does stand ready. Itâs got great liquids outlets and we just basically want to make sure that we donât sell out that capacity too cheaply. Thereâs not a whole lot of that existing capacity and a great liquids market available, and weâre going to make sure we get a premium for having that space available.

componenttext: Well, I would just say this. I think the integrated model from my vantage point of being in the business and working with our E&P group and our gas pipe group has absolutely created a lot of value. However, I think weâve certainly got to look to see the markets fully appreciate that value, and thatâs certainly going to be an important consideration as we look at our alternatives going forward. And weâre looking to create rapidly accelerate shareholder value.

I mean should we be using the strip or you know, if you guys were to say for instance to deploy $1 billion somewhere, what do we take as far as âBoy, this is where they ultimately think gas and oil prices are going to trend out in theâ¦â call it 2020 area for instance?

componenttext: Well, we have obviously several things we do. We have a point of view that past 2012 we havenât published. This is Don. I would say weâre looking at capital redeployment at very attractive after tax rates of return using kind of the price scenario that Ralph laid out with we think a reasonable view of prices, and then also stress testing that and say âHow bad could it be and would we still earn a return thatâs worthwhile?â And if we have terrific opportunities, and particularly if we can do so in a way that broadens our footprint and perhaps also broadens our commodity mix, that would be interesting to us.
In terms of stock buyback, I think our view to date has been in this very low price environment and in a very uncertain economy we just donât have much in the way of firepower to buy back stock without facing ratings downgrade. So as Alan said, all the options are on the table. We continue to look at all the options but to date we have not chosen to go down that path, but as Alan indicated we continue to look at all the options and weâll do that whenever we make a decision on redeploying net capital.

And itâs just we, the rest of the decline that we had, when youâre coming off of for example 28 rigs in the Piceance and youâre going down to what we went down to was then and now weâre at 12, thatâs a huge decline that you overcome when you just look at the way these (inaudible) wells come on, or any kind of wells that we drill now.

You see that we had a 2% growth I believe company-wide sequentially and in the Q3 versus Q2 I think Piceance itself was up 5%. So the big driver will be the Piceance and then also we have the new basin where weâre starting to get a little traction on in the Marcellus. componenttextpreview: Alan, on the liquids volumes for the Q3, they were down sequentially versus the Q2. Can you comment on any outages or what was going on there? Maybe main rejection?
componenttext: Alan, on the liquids volumes for the Q3, they were down sequentially versus the Q2. Can you comment on any outages or what was going on there? Maybe main rejection?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Really there was two primary issues there that did effect it, and you are right - itâs actually a pretty substantial reduction in our equity gallons. First of all in the Mobile Bay area, we had Exxon, who is the big producer into Mobile Bay, had s
componenttext:
Sure. Really there was two primary issues there that did effect it, and you are right - itâs actually a pretty substantial reduction in our equity gallons. First of all in the Mobile Bay area, we had Exxon, who is the big producer into Mobile Bay, had some outages on one of their offshore pipelines completely unrelated to the drilling moratorium that reduced input coming into the plant substantially. In addition to that, though, we also, the way those contracts work, they have rights to take their liquids for a certain number of months over the year, and it just so happened that that piled up, their option piled up in this quarter. Itâs actually our election and so with their outage we elected to give them the liquids in that period when there was an outage. So that was by far the largest.
And then out west we had reduction related to a forced measure that we got from One Oak at their Bushton fractionator, and that backed up all of our plants in the west. They had some difficulties maintaining with the volumes ramping up so rapidly coming out of the west. Theyâve had some difficulties keeping their infrastructure out in front of that, and that resulted in a forced measure that did impact our western volume. So all in all we are really well positioned right now with our Echo plant being now up, which just really got spinning here towards the end of September. And weâve gotten some of the line problems resolved that we had on the Perdito tie in, which were effecting our Markham volumes as well. So going into the Q4 here we are really well positioned to get back on track on our liquids production and grow that pretty rapidly.

componenttext: Most of my questions have actually been answered at this point, but Ralph, I know itâs still very early in the Marcellus for you guys but youâve outlined some particular areas in your presentation. Can you just kind of talk about that from a bigger picture standpoint?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, the Westmoreland County area, and again, we took over operations just a few months ago but what weâre seeing in our first handful, our first several wells there is that 90-day flows in some of the areas are still above or at the 3.5 million a day
componenttext:
Yeah, the Westmoreland County area, and again, we took over operations just a few months ago but what weâre seeing in our first handful, our first several wells there is that 90-day flows in some of the areas are still above or at the 3.5 million a day tide flows, so weâre impressed with that, we like that. So weâre just still learning, understanding, but we like all the areas weâre in. And obviously weâre excited to do a lot more in Susquehanna County. Weâre only running one rig up there now and obviously we have some completions that weâre backing up on because of the delay in the Laser Pipeline.
But in general all the Clearfield, Westmoreland and Centre Counties are doing very well; Westmorelandâs doing slightly better. And I think Susquehanna as you know will do much better than any of those once we get there. So weâre excited. Weâve brought in a fit for purpose Patterson rig, weâve brought in a rig from H&P from the Rockies, so weâre happy to have at least two of those rigs that are fit for purpose. Weâve contracted for some more. And again, itâs just kind of like what we see happening in the Piceance - when you get the right crews, the right equipment, and get the opportunity to move it into more of a scale operation we think the efficiencies will come like weâve seen in the Piceance.

componenttext: Weâre showing in the Piceance Valley we believe our returns are, Iâll just give you a range - 35% to 40%, and in the Highlands theyâre more upper teens, so 17%, 18% type returns. And the Highlands next year all weâre going to drill at this point will be in the Ryan Gulch area. Obviously we pulled that capital so those returns are really focused in the Ryan Gulch, although that still is kind of a combination of what we would call Ryan Gulch/Trail Ridge wells. So Ryan Gulch would have a slightly higher net; the number I gave you in the upper teens is really kind of a hybrid of the Trail Ridge and the Ryan Gulch.

componenttext: Well the valley will clearly grow, and the Highlands has been growing. Itâll be a challenge to keep it flat but the teams, we probably would need to, with two rigs itâll be tight. We may decline in the Highlands some.

componenttext: Really Barnett is much more of a permitting side of the world, which basically is somewhat strange, but itâs on the compression facilities and water facilities. Itâs not the takeaway capacity for us as much as it is on just permits in some of the areas we operate in, on trying to do what we think is the best practice - build centralized water facilities and larger compressor areas just to be more efficient.

componenttext: Yeah, I think we look at all options like that and that is an option thatâs out there. It depends on whatâs going on in the marketplace but Barnett has been frustrating simply from a standpoint of a lot of what we saw was just a complete delay in the opportunities to get the facilities we needed to. It wasnât the drilling permits - just actually to get the facilities done to get our gas to market, and that caused a chain link or chain reaction in losing value.

componenttextpreview: Well, itâs something yeah - weâre required to do. And really in this aspect itâs something we actually look at all the time and in last yearâs queue we basically talked about that there are certain triggers we would look at. One would be if the fo
componenttext: Well, itâs something yeah - weâre required to do. And really in this aspect itâs something we actually look at all the time and in last yearâs queue we basically talked about that there are certain triggers we would look at. One would be if the forward market price, and again this is the forward market price through 2025, would happen to decline by more than 20% we would have to take a look at this. And it did, but we look at it every quarter anyway, but for this particular quarter the forward market price is down substantially and itâs just an automatic check. We donât have the opportunity to pick when we want to do that.

componenttext: Okay, that was just an off the wall question. And then the last question is when you look at potential growth CAPEX, it looks like thereâs a real big chunk of opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico. Could you elaborate on how you think about that going forward?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. A lot of continued opportunity out there. The (inaudible) Canyon area continues to be a very active area and certainly underserved from an infrastructure standpoint, and we think weâre very well positioned to capture some of that business out here
componenttext: Sure. A lot of continued opportunity out there. The (inaudible) Canyon area continues to be a very active area and certainly underserved from an infrastructure standpoint, and we think weâre very well positioned to capture some of that business out here, and as well continuing to grow the infrastructure out of the Eastern Gulf area out of our Devilâs Tower facility as well. So we continue to see a lot of opportunity out there. And our GulfStar generic platform, basically, that is now well designed and really ready to be deployed we think can add a tremendous amount of value to producers out there, and weâre continuing to have a lot of interest in that. I think all that has to really change out there, and Iâm not predicting how rapidly this will change, but I do think that whatâs going to be required is for the producers to gain confidence that even though the moratorium is lifted that permits will actually be processed in a timely basis and in a reasonable fashion. And I think everybodyâs waiting to see on that front. But if that does happen then there is a tremendous resource out there and itâs going to need a lot of infrastructure, and weâre very well positioned to serve that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I think generally from the time that we really start investing dollars on many of those projects to the time weâve got cash flow is about, the smaller projects would maybe be a year and a half and the longer projects would be three years. So the answer to your question is yes, in terms of that capital, those large capital dollars being deployed; however, as you know where weâve got infrastructure already there and production gets tied into that, that comes on pretty rapidly for us. And so thereâs a mix of that, but in terms of the capital, those large chunks of capital that you see in our potential pie there, most of that would be probably in the 2.5 year range from the time that we would be investing heavily to the time weâd see cash flows come back.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Company Third quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Company Third quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our third quarter call this morning. As always, thanks for the interest in the company. Steve Malcolm, our President and CEO, is going to review a few slides that we have prepared for this morning. But
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our third quarter call this morning. As always, thanks for the interest in the company. Steve Malcolm, our President and CEO, is going to review a few slides that we have prepared for this morning. But be aware, though, as always, all of our business unit heads, Alan Armstrong, Ralph Hill, Phil Wright, as well as Don Chappel, the CFO, are here in the room, ready for questions that we'll take after Steve's marks.
This morning on our website, williams.com, you should go to find the slides, the data book, the press release, which were also issued this morning. The third quarter 10-Q will also be available today. You'd be able to access them on the website as well.
At the beginning of the slide deck are the forward-looking statements and the disclaimer on oil and gas reserves. Those are both very important and integral to the remarks, so you should review those.
Also, there are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to generally accepted accounting principles. Those schedules are available and they follow the presentation.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Travis. Welcome to our third quarter earnings call, and thanks for your interest in our company. Let's just dive into the slides. Slide 5 shows the financial, the key financial results. Of course, adjusted earnings per share from continuing o
componenttext:
Thank you, Travis. Welcome to our third quarter earnings call, and thanks for your interest in our company. Let's just dive into the slides. 
Slide 5 shows the financial, the key financial results. Of course, adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations is $0.22 for the third quarter, year-to-date of $0.86, it was 28% higher than 2009.
Our 2010 through '12 earnings guidance is relatively unchanged. We will go into some of the tweaks that we've made here a little later. And we did record a $1.7 billion noncash impairment due to the recent decline in natural gas prices.
Slide 6, please. Some of the major highlights from the quarter. We did reach agreement to sell our Piceance Basin gathering and processing assets to WPZ. I have a slide later that goes into more detail on that transaction.
Secondly, we're very excited about the progress that we're making to grow our businesses in the Marcellus shale. And let me just offer some color on that. In the E&P space, we're now operating 3 rigs. That number will be increasing to 6 by the fourth quarter of 2011. Current returns are greater than 30%. We have seen and expect significant continued improvements, as Williams becomes operator and as we proceed with the large Susquehanna drilling program. As you know, we now have 100,000 net acres at an average cost of less than $7,000 an acre. Gross production near $20 million a day at the end of the third quarter. And the Westmoreland County's slavic trust wells have been the best performing to date.
As well, good growth in the midstream space. We're rapidly expanding the lower mountain midstream gathering system project there will ultimately provide over 1.5 Bcf a day of gathering capacity and 1,400 miles of gathering lines, including 400 new miles of large diameter pipe.
As well, construction has begun on our shamrock compression station, where we'll have an initial capacity of 60 million a day, but is expandable to 350 million a day. And that shamrock station will likely be the largest central delivery point out of the lower mountain system.
As well, we have the Springville system. And we now have all of the right-of-way. We expect we'd begin construction in the first quarter of 2011 and service during 2011. And given the demand from customers, we've upped the project size from a 20-inch to a 24-inch diameter pipeline. So a lot of really exciting things going on in the Marcellus.
Moving back now to talk a little bit more about the highlights on the slide. We did close and finance the Overland Pass Pipeline transaction. And there was strong demand for the WPZ share offering. We did complete the restructuring transaction with the PZMZ merger. We're prepared for a November startup of Sundance trail. We've brought the new Echo Springs CXP 4 into full operation at the end of the third quarter. 
And just to remind you, that TXP 4 plant adds about 350 million a day of processing and 30,000 barrels per day of natural gas liquids production and capacity, roughly doubling what we already had there at Echo Springs.
We increased the WPZ distribution by $0.015, and did announce, as you well know, the leadership succession plan effective January 2011, which has Alan coming onboard as President and CEO.
Slide 7, please. This is the slide just gives the guidance range and midpoints for Henry Hub and Rockies net gas prices, crude oil and the NGO margins and our assumed NGL to crude oil relationship.
And I think there are just 2 points that I would want to make here. One, these are unchanged from the commodity price assumptions that we debut at Barclays. And I guess, the second point is, yes, we have seen natural gas prices fall since then, but we've run the numbers and if you use strip prices, you would really see a de minimis impact on our earnings per share for '11 and '12.
Slide 8, please. The steady growth even on expected low net gas prices that shows just adjusted EPS, adjusted segment profit, cash flow from operations and capital. And just the key points here, earnings per share reflect some tightening of ranges in '11 and '12. Segment profit reflects tightening in '11 and a slight increase in the range in '12. CFFO tightens the range consistent with earnings. 2011 CapEx, we're seeing some carryover from 2010 as well, PZ is with its lower mountain and Piceance growth, that's added a little capital, 2012 capital as well, up a little bit, as a result of lower mountain and Piceance growth.
Slide 9, again, segment profit moving up even during a low net gas price environment. That's good stuff. Slide 10, please. This is the slide that we have been showing the last couple of years, which shows maintenance, the maintenance cap, the maintenance to maintain volumes, the growth projects by year and divided out by WPZ, E&P and other. 
A couple of points here. You'll note in 2010, the blue WPZ growth bar is a little larger. And that's obviously associated with the bargaph transaction, the Piceance gathering and processing transaction that I spoke about earlier.
As well, you'll notice the growth capital, the yellow bar in '10 and '11 and '12 continues to grow quite nicely. Of course, that includes that yellow bar, the other category, includes Canada, where do our first mover technological advantage. We continue to anticipate making significant, attractive investments over the next 3 years.
Slide 11. This is our familiar pie chart for WPZ midstream. And as you well know, we've had success in moving projects. Due to our success from the left to the right, we really see huge growth opportunities in the Marcellus, opportunities out West to expand on our already significant position out there. And we're still excited about what the Gulf offers.
Slide 12, please. The WPZ Gas Pipeline inventory of projects. $1.3 billion represented here. PZ franchise or the Gas Pipeline franchise is a major segment of the nation's energy infrastructure, transporting 12% of the country's gas on any given day. And our Gas Pipeline enterprise produces consistent low-risk, substantial free cash flow.
We've talked about the base hit approach that we've used here. Most of our growth has been and will continue to be from market full projects within our existing footprint, as opposed to, in my view, the more risky producer push pipes, which are dependent on a given supply basin.
I would say looking out into the future, there's a significant opportunity for expansions to serve power generation, particularly in the Southeast U.S.
Slide 13, please. I think you're familiar with our premier E&P portfolio. And we have talked in the past that the Marcellus will soon become our second largest producing basin. A couple of other key points. Our drilling returns remain strong and our major operating areas of the Piceance, Marcellus and Powder River with returns ranging from 17% to near 40%, even in the slow net gas price environment.
A major reason for this is our industry leadership position on low cost. And I think a great example here is in the Piceance, for 2010, we've improved our well costs by 3% to 6% versus 2009. 
We have a unique industry portfolio that allows us to flex up our drilling program, up or down, without losing value or losing leases. And as discussed in our September guidance update, we decreased our rig counts for 2011 by 9 rigs, in 2012, by 17 rigs from our previous guidance. And simply put, we can do that and yet preserve our value and leases, while we wait for gas prices to improve. And we still expect to grow our production by 3% in 2011, 7% in 2012.
Slide 14. This is the drop-down slide. So this is a large scale asset, and you see the bullet points on the left there. 150 miles of large diameter pipe, next to 3,300 wells, 6 aiming and treating facilities, 160,000 horsepower of compression, 1.2 Bcf a day of due point processing capacity. So these are significant assets.
The attractive financial profile in some of the key points there. $105 million of WPZ segment profit and DD&A in 2011, immediately accretive to Bcf for PZ. And as a general partner, Williams will receive the favor distribution increased. WPZ is acquiring the fee business. That's good stuff. William CMP segment retains liquids upside, and we have a life of lease dedication from William CMP. And we expect closing to occur in November of 2010.
We still get a lot of questions, and there's a lot of dialogue in the industry about what's going to happen with NGLs and ethane and ethylene. And I'm certainly not going to repeat all of these bullet points, but there are some points that I would want to make.
And we've made these in the past, and continue to believe in them. Short term, the fundamentals remain very strong for our near-term ethane demand, as ethane is maintaining its favorable position in being the low-cost feedstock for ethylene production.
Other people are worried about the shale plays and the larger supplies of ethane that are going to come on. But you have to remember, large supplies of ethane from the shale plays will require significant infrastructure, and infrastructure takes time. The very strong ethylene markets will incent plants to invest in small plant expansions. And WMD Williams has a low-cost expansion investment ongoing at Geismar, which is going to increase our capacity by 12%.
Longer-term, clearly, the U.S. right now holds a large advantage for being the next low-cost tranche of ethylene production, given the abundant natural gas supplies. The U.S. should be in a strong position to export these ethylene derivative products at a lower cost than incremental production elsewhere in the world. And I think, ultimately, the big question is, will ethylene capacity be expanded to keep pace with increased NGL supplies here in the U.S.? And given the high ethane to ethylene spreads that exist, we think, ultimately, that conversions and low-cost capacity increases will happen.
Slide 16 and 17 talk about the progress that we've made on the 2010 priorities for value creation. And you can see more and more of the boxes now have checkmarks. And so we're pleased with the progress that we're making there.
Slide 18, please. Why Williams is a winning investment? No change here. We think that we have the assets, the people. We have proven that we can execute crisply around our strategies. We are committed to financial discipline and believe that we're going to have very, very attractive results in the future.
Before we go to Q&A, I've got a few comments and Alan will as well. But I wanted to address questions about my decision to retire. There's no hidden intrigue or backstory here. As Gwen and I were thinking about the next chapter in our life and having been with Williams for 26 years, 9 of those as CEO, we decided that, again, started talking about it over the summer and ultimately, decided that it made sense for us to retire at the end of 2010.
And as you know, the requirements are such that once you make your final decision, you need to make it public in the 4 or 5 days. So it's a decision that we're very excited about.
But the Board was well-prepared for this decision we've had an active and comprehensive succession planning process in place. The Board and I are confident in the team and confident in Alan Armstrong, and believe that Alan will take the company to new heights. I've had a great opportunity to work with Alan, not only in his role as heading up our Midstream group, but I've worked closely with him back in the 1990s, when I was running Midstream.
So -- and I don't want to get too carried away here, but the experience and culture here at Williams is very unique. And I've been proud to work here for the last 26 years. I truly believe the Williams experience, the Williams culture, is a competitive advantage for us.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. First of all, Steve, I want to make sure that we acknowledge the accomplishments that Steve brought forth. If you take back to the very difficult and tenuous circumstances that Steve was handed and to where he brought us to today with a very strong
componenttext:
Great. First of all, Steve, I want to make sure that we acknowledge the accomplishments that Steve brought forth. If you take back to the very difficult and tenuous circumstances that Steve was handed and to where he brought us to today with a very strong, very stable company with tremendous potential to create shareholder value from where we sit today. We have that potential in terms of financial resources. We've got extremely well-positioned assets in the markets they serve, and we've got tremendous organizational capabilities in terms of exporting resource play, both in our E&P group and in our midstream group, and our pipes are well positioned to serve the change in the markets today associated with the resource plays.
And certainly, as Steve mentioned, our culture with one of the most passionate and committed workforces in the business today, leave me with a tremendous amount of optimism about where we can take this. And I just want to say a big thanks to Steve for giving us such a tremendous platform to take the company on today.
So we are in a very enviable position. We've got all the tools necessary to really accelerate shareholder value. We're going to be reviewing all alternatives. And I'm charged up and can assure you that with the great platform, the well-positioned assets and organizational capabilities that we have today, we will not be sitting still. I don't have any particular bias, other than to assure ourselves that we are creating the most shareholder value that is enduring and allows our businesses to be the most successful they can be for the benefit of our investors.
And with that, I will turn this over to Q&A.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Craig Shere with Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Craig Shere with Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Steve, congratulations on really rebuilding the company from dire days, early in the last decade, and good luck on your retirement. A couple of questions here. Ralph, can you comment on how the commodity price assumptions underlying the guidance of 3%
componenttext: And Steve, congratulations on really rebuilding the company from dire days, early in the last decade, and good luck on your retirement. A couple of questions here. Ralph, can you comment on how the commodity price assumptions underlying the guidance of 3% and 7% production throughout the next couple of years, this resume the decision to write down some E&P properties? And at the current lower strips, is it reasonable to assume the gas production may be declining?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the goodwill impairment and the impairment of the primarily Burnett area is really is an accounting exercise that we work on, and it's basically there are several models there as the fair value model, and gross cash flows are discounted against that
componenttext: Well, the goodwill impairment and the impairment of the primarily Burnett area is really is an accounting exercise that we work on, and it's basically there are several models there as the fair value model, and gross cash flows are discounted against that. So as we look at that, for example, on the goodwill, the internal fair value was slightly less than the carrying value. And in that case, it caused an impairment of our goodwill, which was -- goodwill for us was associated with the 2001, almost a decade ago, acquisition of Barrett. And it wasn't cash out the door. It was really deferred tax liability gross-up, if you will. And that became our goodwill. And over the course of the last decade, as we look to prices and all that, we really didn't have any opportunities for impairment than with the 4 price curve has gone down greater than 22%, since the beginning of the year, that caused us to look at that and that caused that write down. For the Barnett, it was simply just a factor of the fair value again versus the carrying value. Barnett ford prices has come down substantially. And we have that impairment. That really doesn't have anything to do with go forward on where we're headed primarily in the Piceance and in the Marcellus, where most of our donors and lesser extent, the powder. So those are just accounting exercises. If you look at it, you understand the value of what you're carrying versus the value of the fair value. And those were impaired from there. And I don't know if your last question is more about the industry or us. We know that the level of rigs that, which we did drop a substantial amount of rigs in our forecasts at the Barclays conference for '11 and '12. But we know that we believe our production is growing that much. I think the industry in general, hopefully, at some time, we'll see our competitors put on more of a return hat and finished drilling for holding leases and finish drilling for holding JVs. And we'll see a more rational response to the gas prices. And therefore, at that point, I would expect to see some of the gas supply to decline.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, I'm trying to understand is the write-down based on forward strips, which are meaningfully below your midpoint guidance assumptions for the next 2 years? And if we incorporated that more conservative assumption, given the wide range of CapE
componenttext: Well, I guess, I'm trying to understand is the write-down based on forward strips, which are meaningfully below your midpoint guidance assumptions for the next 2 years? And if we incorporated that more conservative assumption, given the wide range of CapEx guidance for the next couple of years, is it reasonable to assume that we trend towards the lower end, is what I'm trying to get at.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It is based on, really, what happened is the strips, 20, 25 is down about. I mentioned greater than 20%. And I would say, at this point, I would not trend towards the lower part. We feel confident that our drilling program, as I think, Steve mentioned, ou
componenttext: It is based on, really, what happened is the strips, 20, 25 is down about. I mentioned greater than 20%. And I would say, at this point, I would not trend towards the lower part. We feel confident that our drilling program, as I think, Steve mentioned, our returns in the areas we're going to be drilling are anywhere from 17% to near 40%. We have cut our drilling programs substantially. But at this point, we feel that we'll be, we don't give out exactly, we get approved wide range. I think most of you guys look at the middle part of that range, and that's kind of what you assume. And that's generally where we try to come out. If prices would continue to come down, substantially, we always have the ability, as Steve said, to flex our portfolio down, our drilling program down and respond according until prices come the right way.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And one other quick question, guys. I don't know if Don or Alan or Steve want to fill this., But do I understand that the latest drop-down to WPZ pre-tax, the WMD, may have been 7.5x EBITDA and after-tax maybe 6.5x? And does that seem a little low
componenttext: Great. And one other quick question, guys. I don't know if Don or Alan or Steve want to fill this., But do I understand that the latest drop-down to WPZ pre-tax, the WMD, may have been 7.5x EBITDA and after-tax maybe 6.5x? And does that seem a little low for fee-based business? And how does that correlates to maybe future dropdowns and how you would envision pricing?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Don. I might just comment. You have to remember that Williams pertains its GP interest. And with that, we get a substantial, you could call it a royalty. But we get a substantial profit participation in that asset, despite the fact we dropp
componenttext: Craig, this is Don. I might just comment. You have to remember that Williams pertains its GP interest. And with that, we get a substantial, you could call it a royalty. But we get a substantial profit participation in that asset, despite the fact we dropped it down. So I think when you look at the GP interest on top of what we actually sold in 4 in terms of cash, I think you'd get a much higher valuation. And in terms of what's left to drop-down, we have a 25.5% interest in gulf stream, which is eligible beginning kind of late first quarter. That's not guidance in terms of what we may do, but it would be eligible for drop-down kind of late first quarter. And beyond that, we really haven't earmarked any other assets.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Our next question will come from Lawson Jong with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Recently, just a couple of your competitors have decided to dance and leave you guys out of it, creating some new projects in the Marcellus and the Eagleford. Does this signal a change in how you would pursue the McClellan natural expansion and the Eaglef
componenttext: Recently, just a couple of your competitors have decided to dance and leave you guys out of it, creating some new projects in the Marcellus and the Eagleford. Does this signal a change in how you would pursue the McClellan natural expansion and the Eagleford and the Keystone connector in the Marcellus?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me tackle -- this is Phil Wright. Let me tackle the Keystone connector. It doesn't change anything with respect to what we're pursuing on that project, and we continue to work with producers. As you know, the difficulty in achieving success on any of
componenttext: Let me tackle -- this is Phil Wright. Let me tackle the Keystone connector. It doesn't change anything with respect to what we're pursuing on that project, and we continue to work with producers. As you know, the difficulty in achieving success on any of those large infrastructure projects is getting producers to a position where they have a clear enough vision of what their needs are going to be and what markets they want to try to serve sufficient to sign a precedent agreement that would produce enough security around the project that would have an investment profile attractive enough to proceed. And I think that chicken and egg problem persists. With respect to the McMullan lateral, I know Alan will have some probably from the midstream perspective. But from the pipeline perspective, I can tell you that as more drilling is done out there and as the lenses of liquids-rich and oil-rich finds sort of move northward, we're seeing a higher level of interest in dry gas. But nonetheless, a very high level of interest in the McMullan lateral.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All I would add to that in terms of the, first o fall, in terms of the Marcellus is, we have a tremendous joint venture in our Atlas joint venture with Atlas called the lower Mountain. Outstanding growth alternatives coming out of that. And we've got some
componenttext: All I would add to that in terms of the, first o fall, in terms of the Marcellus is, we have a tremendous joint venture in our Atlas joint venture with Atlas called the lower Mountain. Outstanding growth alternatives coming out of that. And we've got some exciting developments going on, on the north end of our Springville lateral. And so I don't feel like we're being left out in any way, shape or form. In fact, I would tell you, I think we probably have one of the strongest JVs in the Marcellus from a midstream perspective in terms of creating shareholder value going up there. So I'm very excited about that position. In terms of Eagleford, the Markham plant, which is primarily positioned to serve in the deep water Gulf of Mexico, does stay and ready, and it's gotten great liquids outlets and we just basically, we want to make sure that we don't sell out that capacity too cheaply. There's not a whole lot of that existing capacity and great liquids market available. And we're going to make sure we get a premium for having that space available.

componenttextpreview: Well, I would just say this. I think the integrated model, from my vantage point of being in the business and working with our E&P group and our gas pipe group, has absolutely created a lot of value. However, I think we certainly got to look to see that t
componenttext: Well, I would just say this. I think the integrated model, from my vantage point of being in the business and working with our E&P group and our gas pipe group, has absolutely created a lot of value. However, I think we certainly got to look to see that the markets fully appreciate the value, and that's certainly going to be an important consideration, as we look at our alternatives going forward. So I think it's very early for you to conclude, or anybody to include, really, where we stand on that because we will be looking at our alternatives. But I can assure you that everything is on the table, and we will be not looking to sit still. So -- and we're looking to create rapidly accelerated shareholder value.

componenttext: Well, this is Ralph. We had a previous forecast that had, I think, our growth was going to be 12% next year and then 16% the year after. And what we did is we essentially dropped about 10 rigs in 2011 and about, I think it was 17 rigs in 2012's forecast. So we have the ability to go out and that wouldn't all happen in 6 months. But we have the ability to rapidly ramp it back up if prices signals would show that. And obviously, as Don would point out, that as our cash flows would grow, then that's what we try to live within our means. So I don't know how much would happen in 6 months. But I can tell you, a few months ago, we were planning on, with the different price tag, to have a substantial higher level of growth, and we've dialed that back to the prices.

componenttext: I think I said it well. Obviously, the Eagleford and the Bakken bring a different look to our portfolio in a sense of liquids and to our condensate oil, which is we'd like to have that. But expertise-wise, we drilled hundreds and hundreds of horizontal wells. We understand how to do that. So each of those areas work for us. So we continue to -- now we have a substantial position in the Marcellus of 100,000 acres. We'd like to continue to and evaluate opportunities there, and we are. Eagleford had some great-looking opportunities out there. And obviously, there's other areas, such as the Bakken that we think it fit right in what our expertise is.

componenttext: This is Don. We've asked our E&P business largely to live within its means. So to the extent it generates cash flows, we have expected they would likely consume those cash flows to reinvest in the business, again, with a bias towards liquids rich areas, like the Pineance, In fact, we do get a lot of liquids out of the Pineance. And I'd say that the WPZ Midstream investment and gas pipeline assets are well capitalized with a very low cost of capital. So really, I don't see too much in the way of corporate capital moving back into that business for the foreseeable future.

componenttext: Well, certainly, we are pursuing those that give us a large-scale position out there. And I've got pretty high hopes that we'll be able to deliver on something of similar nature to what we had in Lower Mountain area. On top of that, however, there are a tremendous amount of those producers that we were talking to that infill into those assets that  we're developing. And things like the Laurel Mountain JV and other alternatives up in the Northeast Pennsylvania area, we think are going to give us first mover advantage allows to serve those remaining producers that we're talking to. So we're out there aggressively pursuing large anchor customers. And then we'll be in a position to better serve the balance of those customers.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Well, I would just tell you that the process of negotiating, these are very long-term, obviously, those reserves are extremely long life. And so the contracts for them are fairly complex because they're meant to be very enduring. And so it just takes a while to get through the contracting stage. But we are making very good progress on those fronts and look forward to making some announcements on that not very distant future. So don't assume lack of us announcing anything is lack of progress. We've got, actually, quite a bit of progress that's going on in the last quarter there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Appreciate those comments. And maybe one other question, if I could, for Ralph. Recognizing this is always a bit of a moving target. But in conjunction with the back end of the curve coming down, as you guys are looking to potentially deploy more capital
componenttext: Appreciate those comments. And maybe one other question, if I could, for Ralph. Recognizing this is always a bit of a moving target. But in conjunction with the back end of the curve coming down, as you guys are looking to potentially deploy more capital outside of the Rockies, what should we think about what you guys are using for sort of a long-term clearing price of oil and gas? I mean, should we be using the strip? Or if you guys were, say, for instance, to deploy $1 billion somewhere, what do we take as far as, boy, this is where they ultimately think gas and oil prices are going to trend out in the, call it, 20 20 area, for instance?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have, obviously, several things we do. We have a point of view that past 2012, we haven't published. We also have the market that we look at closely and we monitor what's going on in the market at all times. And then we run low cases, and we run
componenttext: Well, we have, obviously, several things we do. We have a point of view that past 2012, we haven't published. We also have the market that we look at closely and we monitor what's going on in the market at all times. And then we run low cases, and we run high cases, and we run stress cases. So I'm sorry I can't give you an exact answer because we run a number of cases. We typically, our point of view, from time to time is pretty close to what the market's doing. That just happens, just the way it works out. But we look at so many different scenarios, it's hard to tell you exactly. But I can tell you, when we do look at all these, we severely stress test them to understand what it means in a low-price environment, both for the gas side and the oil side.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Just most of my questions have been touched. Just wanted to ask with the announcement to sell the midstream assets to PC, I mean, it sounds like you want to deploy capital into more E&P assets. How do you weigh that against potentially doing a share repurchase?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Don. I would say, we're looking at capital redeployment, that very attractive after-tax rates return using kind of the price scenario that Ralph laid out with we think a reasonable view of prices. And then also, stress testing that, and say, how b
componenttext: This is Don. I would say, we're looking at capital redeployment, that very attractive after-tax rates return using kind of the price scenario that Ralph laid out with we think a reasonable view of prices. And then also, stress testing that, and say, how bad could it be and would we still earn a return that was worthwhile. And if we have terrific opportunities and particularly, if we can do so on a way that broadens our footprint and perhaps also broadens our commodity mix, that would be interesting to us. In terms of stock buyback, I think our view to date has been in this very low-price environment and with a very uncertain economy, we just really don't have much in the way of fire to buy back stock without facing ratings downgrade. So we've, as Alan said, all the options are on the table. We continue to look at all the options. But to date, we've not chosen to go down that path. But again, as Alan indicated, we continue to look at all the options, and we'll do that whenever we make a decision on redeploying that capital.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But if I hear you correctly, the preference is for to do a E&P acquisition versus share buybacks?
componenttext: But if I hear you correctly, the preference is for to do a E&P acquisition versus share buybacks?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, I mean, clearly, we think that the share price is an attractive one. But we certainly don't want to face a downgrade in order to do that because that has a broader implications. So we'll look at the options, We'll look at the potential consequenc
componenttext: I think, I mean, clearly, we think that the share price is an attractive one. But we certainly don't want to face a downgrade in order to do that because that has a broader implications. So we'll look at the options, We'll look at the potential consequences and benefits, and make a decision that we think is in the best interest of the company and shareholders.

componenttext: Well, this is Ralph. I wouldn't comment at all on the imminent side of the world. But I can tell you that there, as you probably know, there are a number of opportunities in all these basins. There always are. But there appear to be more than normal at this time. So there's just a lot of opportunities there. But as Don had said and Steve had said and Alan said, that there are a number of things we take into account when we look at that. And so we evaluate continuously, my group and the rest of the groups here at Williams, opportunities. We see when we think straight value, we bring it to the table and we talk about it and we try to see if that's something we want to do. So there's just a lot out there right now, but they're typically is in this industry.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just the, it's really the -- yes, you are accurate in looking at it that way. It's just we have rested the decline that we had when you're coming off, for example, a 28 rigs in the Piceance and you're going down to what we went down to as 10, a
componenttext: Well, it's just the, it's really the -- yes, you are accurate in looking at it that way. It's just we have rested the decline that we had when you're coming off, for example, a 28 rigs in the Piceance and you're going down to what we went down to as 10, and now we're at 12, that's a huge decline that you overcome when you just look at the way these type wells come on and already kind of wells that we drill now. So we've overcome that decline for the number of rigs that we drop. And now that we've done that, the volumes are starting to tweak back up. You see we had a 2% growth, I believe, company-wide, sequentially in the third quarter versus second quarter, I think Piceance itself is up 5%. So the big driver will be the Piceance. And then also, we have the new basin, where we started to get a little traction on in the Marcellus. But you are seeing it correctly, that we have arrested the decline. We're actually growing again, and we expect a decent growth in the fourth quarter.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alan, on the liquids volumes for the third quarter, they were down sequentially versus the second quarter. Can you comment on any outages and what was going on there? Maybe projection?
componenttext: Alan, on the liquids volumes for the third quarter, they were down sequentially versus the second quarter. Can you comment on any outages and what was going on there? Maybe projection?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Really, there was 2 primary issues there that did affect it. And you are right, it's actually fairly substantial reduction in our equity gallons. First of all, in the Mobile Bay area, we had Exxon, who is the big producer into Mobile Bay, had some o
componenttext: Sure. Really, there was 2 primary issues there that did affect it. And you are right, it's actually fairly substantial reduction in our equity gallons. First of all, in the Mobile Bay area, we had Exxon, who is the big producer into Mobile Bay, had some outages on one of their offshore pipelines, completely unrelated to the drilling moratorium that reduced input coming into the plant substantially. In addition to that, though, we also, the way those contracts work, they have rights to take their liquids for a certain number of months out of the year. And it just so happened that 2 of those that piled up, they're option piled up in this quarter. It's actually our election. And so with their outage, we elected to give them the liquids in that period, where there was an outage. So that was by far the largest. And then out West, we had reduction related to a force majeure that we got from one at their Bush infractionator. And that backed up all of our plants in the West. They had some difficulties maintaining with the volumes ramping up so rapidly, coming out of the West, they've had some difficult keeping our infrastructure out in front of that. And that resulted in a force majeure that did impact over western volumes. So all in all, we are really well-positioned right now with our eco plant being now up, which just really got spinning here towards in to September. And we've gotten the some of the line problems resolved that we had on the ready tie in, which were affecting our mark and volumes as well. So going into the fourth quarter here, we are really well-positioned to get back on track on our liquids production and grow that pretty rapidly.

componenttext: We've done that a little bit last year, and then primarily is in the Powder. And so we look at it from time to time. But we're, at this point, we're not contemplating any of that. We're about 56%, 60% hedged. We have a number of things that go into that, if you're shutting in that complicate that. So it needs to be more than a, or it would need to be for a substantial period of time. We don't see a reason to do that.

componenttextpreview: Well, it depends on where you're looking and if you're in the sweet spots or not. But we think, generally, we think we know what the markets, where the market is in our area of interest. We feel we know what it takes to win in certain areas. So to the ext
componenttext: Well, it depends on where you're looking and if you're in the sweet spots or not. But we think, generally, we think we know what the markets, where the market is in our area of interest. We feel we know what it takes to win in certain areas. So to the extent, we find something we think, from a technical standpoint, hits our sweet spot, then I think that's when we look to try to move something forward. So as so many transactions are out there, it's hard to say which ones are good or bad. But we look at it first from the chemical standpoint, if our exploration team likes it, our engineer likes it evaluate, it hits at we evaluate as a, what we call the sweet spot, then that's something we'll be more aggressive at looking at and other fresh areas.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Okay, got you. And with the write down that you guys took, is there going to be any impacted DD&A reserves?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The reserves the activity, we do, yes, the reserves are based on different things. The reserves are basically on the average of the 12, first month prices for 12 months. And the gas prices this year are higher than last year, if you average that in. So th
componenttext: The reserves the activity, we do, yes, the reserves are based on different things. The reserves are basically on the average of the 12, first month prices for 12 months. And the gas prices this year are higher than last year, if you average that in. So that array impacts on reserves. On DD&A, yes, we do see an impact. Our DD&A, it's probably going to go down about $0.10 to $0.15 company-wide for 2011 and about $0.10 again in 2012. That has been baked into the guidance. Basically, as you see the previous guidance and we, at that time, we own what we call the Piceance gathering assets, we also call that bargas. We own those. They were previously in our guidance. Now, it's out of our guidance. But we did get some DD&A pickup on the other side. So in general, you see our guidance didn't really change. They kind of offset each other.
