headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I think we look at all options like that, and that is an option that's out there. It depends on what's going on in the marketplace. But the Barnett has been frustrating simply from a standpoint of -- a lot of what we saw was just a complete delay in th
componenttext: So I think we look at all options like that, and that is an option that's out there. It depends on what's going on in the marketplace. But the Barnett has been frustrating simply from a standpoint of -- a lot of what we saw was just a complete delay in the opportunity to get the facilities we needed to. It wasn't the drilling permits. It's just actually getting the facilities done to get our gas to market. And that caused a chain link or a chain reaction in losing value.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you have discretion in terms of the timing of the write-down? Could you have waited until you reported year end to do that? Or was it something that you were required to do at this time?
componenttext: Did you have discretion in terms of the timing of the write-down? Could you have waited until you reported year end to do that? Or was it something that you were required to do at this time?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's something we're -- yes, we're required to do. They're really -- and in this aspect, it's something we actually look at all the time. And then in the last year's queue, we basically talked about it. There are certain triggers we were looking at,
componenttext: Well, it's something we're -- yes, we're required to do. They're really -- and in this aspect, it's something we actually look at all the time. And then in the last year's queue, we basically talked about it. There are certain triggers we were looking at, one would be at the forward market price, and again, this is a forward market price, like 2025 would have a decline by more than 20%. We would have to take a look at this, and we did. But we look at it every quarter anyway. But for this particular quarter, the forward market price is down substantially. And it's just an automatic check. There's no -- we don't have the opportunity to pick when we want to do that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that was just off-the-wall question. And then the last question is when you look at potential growth CapEx, it looks like there's a real big chunk of opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico. Could you elaborate on how you think about that going forward?
componenttext: Okay, that was just off-the-wall question. And then the last question is when you look at potential growth CapEx, it looks like there's a real big chunk of opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico. Could you elaborate on how you think about that going forward?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. A lot of continued opportunity out there. The Canyon area continues to be a very active area and certainly underserved from an infrastructure standpoint. And we think we're very well positioned to capture some of that business out there. And as well
componenttext: Sure. A lot of continued opportunity out there. The Canyon area continues to be a very active area and certainly underserved from an infrastructure standpoint. And we think we're very well positioned to capture some of that business out there. And as well, continuing to grow the infrastructure out of the Eastern Gulf area out of our Devil's Tower facility as well. So we continue to see a lot of opportunity out there. And our GulfStar generic platform, basically, that is now well designed and really ready to be deployed. We think it can add a tremendous amount of value to producers out there. And we're continuing to have a lot of interest in that. I think all of it has really changed out there. And I'm not predicting how rapidly this will change, but I do think what's going to be required is for the producers to gain confidence that even though the moratorium is lifted, that permits will actually be processed in a timely basis and in a recent fashion. And I think everybody's waiting to see on that front. But if it does happen, then there is tremendous resource out there, and it's going to need a lot of infrastructure, and we're very well positioned to serve that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just from the realization of cash flow. Is that a long lead time? Would you be able to do it incrementally? Or would there be a big lag between dollars invested and at the start of incremental cash?
componenttext: And just from the realization of cash flow. Is that a long lead time? Would you be able to do it incrementally? Or would there be a big lag between dollars invested and at the start of incremental cash?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think generally from the time that we really start investing dollars on many of those projects to the time we've got cash flow is about -- the smaller projects would may be, be 1.5 years and the longer projects would be 3 years. So to answer your q
componenttext: Yes, I think generally from the time that we really start investing dollars on many of those projects to the time we've got cash flow is about -- the smaller projects would may be, be 1.5 years and the longer projects would be 3 years. So to answer your question is yes, in terms of that capital, those large capital dollars being deployed. However, as you know, where we've got infrastructure already there and production gets tied into that, that comes on pretty rapidly for us. And so there's a mix of that. But in terms of the capital, those large chunks of capital that you see in our potential pie there, most of that would be probably in the 2.5-year range from the time we would be investing heavily to the time we would see cash flows come back.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: This is Don. On your impairment question, I just remind everyone that in 2008, 2009, many, many companies across the industry took very large write-downs. We did not. So while we took the write-down this quarter, we haven't had any large write-downs back in the '08, '09 period when many, many other write-downs were taken.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies' Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Ple
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies' Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our third quarter call this morning. As always, thanks for the interest in the company. Steve Malcolm, our President and CEO, is going to review a few slides that we have prepared for this morning. But
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our third quarter call this morning. As always, thanks for the interest in the company. Steve Malcolm, our President and CEO, is going to review a few slides that we have prepared for this morning. But be aware, though, as always, all of our business unit heads, Alan Armstrong, Ralph Hill, Phil Wright, as well as Don Chappel, the CFO, are here in the room, ready for questions that we'll take after Steve's remarks.
This morning on our website, williams.com, you should be able to find the slides, the data book, the press release, which were all issued this morning. The third quarter 10-Q will also be available today. You'd be able to access that on the website as well.
At the beginning of the slide deck are the forward-looking statements and the disclaimer on oil and gas reserves. Those are all -- those are both very important and integral to the remarks, so you should review those.
Also, there are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to generally accepted accounting principles. Those schedules are available and they follow the presentation.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Travis. Welcome to our third quarter earnings call, and thanks for your interest in our company. Let's just dive into the slides. Slide 5 shows the financial -- the key financial results. Of course, adjusted earnings per share from continuing
componenttext:
Thank you, Travis. Welcome to our third quarter earnings call, and thanks for your interest in our company. Let's just dive into the slides. 
Slide 5 shows the financial -- the key financial results. Of course, adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations is $0.22 for the third quarter. Year-to-date of $0.86 is 28% higher than 2009. Our 2010 through '12 earnings guidance is relatively unchanged. We will go into some of the tweaks that we've made here a little later. And we did record a $1.7 billion noncash impairment due to the recent decline in natural gas prices.
Slide 6, please. Some of the major highlights from the quarter. We did reach agreement to sell our Piceance Basin gathering and processing assets to WPZ. I have a slide later that goes into more detail on that transaction. Secondly, we're very excited about the progress that we're making to grow our businesses in the Marcellus shale. And let me just offer some color on that. In the E&P space, we're now operating 3 rigs. That number will be increasing to 6 by the fourth quarter of 2011. Current returns are greater than 30%. We have seen and expect significant continued improvements, as Williams becomes operator and as we proceed with the large Susquehanna drilling program. As you know, we now have 100,000 net acres at an average cost of less than $7,000 an acre. Gross production near $20 million a day at the end of the third quarter. And the Westmoreland County Slavic Trust wells have been the best performing to date.
As well, good growth in the midstream space. We're rapidly expanding the Laurel Mountain midstream gathering system. Projects there will ultimately provide over 1.5 Bcf a day of gathering capacity and 1,400 miles of gathering lines, including 400 new miles of large diameter pipe.
As well, construction has begun on our Shamrock compressor station, where we'll have an initial capacity of 60 million a day. That is expandable to 350 million a day. And that Shamrock station will likely be the largest central delivery point out of the Laurel Mountain system.
As well, we have the Springville system. And we now have all of the right of way. We expect we'd begin construction in the first quarter of 2011, in service during 2011. And given the demand from customers, we've upped the project size from a 20-inch to a 24-inch diameter pipeline. So a lot of really exciting things going on in the Marcellus.
Moving back now to talk a little bit more about the highlights on the slide. We did close and finance the Overland Pass Pipeline transaction. And there was strong demand for the WPZ share offering. We did complete the restructuring transaction with the PZ-MZ merger. We're prepared for a November startup of Sundance Trail. We've brought the new Echo Springs TXP-4 into full operation at the end of the third quarter. And just to remind you, the TXP-4 plant adds about 350 million a day of processing and 30,000 barrels per day of natural gas liquids production and capacity, roughly doubling what we already had there at Echo Springs.
We increased the WPZ distribution by $0.015 and did announce, as you well know, the leadership succession plan effective January 2011, which has Alan coming onboard as President and CEO.
Slide 7, please. This is -- this slide just gives the guidance range and midpoints for Henry Hub and Rockies, net gas prices, crude oil and the NGO margins and our assumed NGL to crude oil relationship.
And I think there are just 2 points that I would want to make here. One, these are unchanged from the commodity price assumptions that we gave you at Barclays. And I guess, the second point is, yes, we have seen natural gas prices fall since then, but we've run the numbers and if you ran -- if you use strip prices, you would really see a de minimis impact on our earnings per share for '11 and '12.
Slide 8, please. The steady growth even on expected low net gas prices. This shows adjusted EPS, adjusted segment profit, cash flow from operations and capital. And just the key points here, earnings per share reflects some tightening of ranges in '11 and '12. Segment profit reflects tightening in '11 and a slight increase in the range in '12. CFFO tightens the range consistent with earnings. 2011 CapEx, we're seeing some carryover from 2010 as well, PZ is with its Laurel Mountain and Piceance growth, that's added a little capital. 2012 capital as well, up a little bit, as a result of Laurel Mountain and Piceance growth.
Slide 9, again, segment profit moving up even during a low net gas price environment. That's good stuff. Slide 10, please. This is the slide that we have been showing the last couple of years, which shows maintenance, the maintenance cap, the maintenance to maintain volumes, the growth projects by year and divided out by WPZ, E&P and other. 
A couple of points here. You'll note in 2010, the blue WPZ growth bar is a little larger. And that's obviously associated with the bar GAP transaction, the Piceance gathering and processing transaction that I spoke about earlier.
As well, you'll notice the growth capital, the yellow bar in '10 and '11 and '12 continues to grow quite nicely. Of course, that includes, the yellow bar, the other category, includes Canada, where due  our first mover technological advantage, we continue to anticipate making significant, attractive investments over the next 3 years.
Slide 11. This is our familiar pie chart for WPZ midstream. And as you well know, we've had success in moving projects. Due to our success from the left to the right, we really see huge growth opportunities in the Marcellus, opportunities out West to expand on our already significant position out there. And we're still excited about what the Gulf offers.
Slide 12 please, the WPZ gas pipeline inventory of projects. $1.3 billion represented here. PZ franchise or the gas pipeline franchise is a major segment of the nation's energy infrastructure, transporting 12% of the country's gas on any given day. And our gas pipeline enterprise produces consistent, low-risk, substantial free cash flow.  We've talked about the base hit approach that we've used here. Most of our growth has been and will continue to be from market full projects within our existing footprint, as opposed to, in my view, the more risky producer push pipes, which are dependent on a given supply basin.  I would say looking out into the future, there's a significant opportunity for expansions to serve power generation, particularly in the Southeast U.S..
Slide 13 please. I think you're familiar with our premier E&P portfolio. And we have talked in the past that the Marcellus will soon become our second largest producing basin. A couple of other key points. Our drilling returns remain strong in our major operating areas of the Piceance, Marcellus and Powder River with returns ranging from 17% to near 40%, even in this low net gas price environment. A major reason for this is our industry leadership position on low cost. And I think a great example here is in the Piceance, for 2010, we've improved our well costs by 3% to 6% versus 2009. 
We have a unique industry portfolio that allows us to flex up our drilling program, up or down, without losing value or losing leases. And as discussed in our September guidance update, we decreased our rig counts for 2011 by 9 rigs, and in 2012, by 17 rigs from our previous guidance. And simply put, we can do that and yet preserve our value and leases, while we wait for gas prices to improve. And we still expect to grow our production by 3% in 2011, 7% in 2012.
Slide 14. This is the drop-down slide. So this is a large-scale asset, and you see the bullet points on the left there. 150 miles of large-diameter pipe, connects to 3,300 wells, 6 amine treating facilities, 160,000 horsepower of compression, 1.2 Bcf a day of dew-point processing capacity. So these are significant assets.  The attractive financial profile and some other key points there. $105 million of WPZ segment profit and DD&A in 2011, immediately accretive to DCF for PZ. And as a general partner, Williams will receive a favored distribution increase. WPZ is acquiring fee business. That's good stuff. Williams E&P segment retains liquids upside, and we have a life-of-lease dedication from Williams E&P. And we expect closing to occur in November of 2010.
We still get a lot of questions, and there's a lot of dialogue in the industry about what's going to happen with NGLs and ethane and ethylene. And I'm certainly not going to repeat all of these bullet points, but there are some points that I would want to make. And we've made these in the past and continue to believe in them. Short term, the fundamentals remain very strong for our near-term ethane demand, as ethane is maintaining its favorable position in being the low-cost feedstock for ethylene production.
A lot of people are worried about the shale plays and the large supplies of ethane that are going to come on. But you have to remember, large supplies of ethane from the shale plays will require significant infrastructure and infrastructure takes time. The very strong ethylene markets will incent plants to invest in small plant expansions. And WMB Williams has a low-cost expansion investment ongoing at Geismar, which is going to increase our capacity by 12%.
Longer term, clearly, the U.S. right now holds a large advantage for being the next low-cost tranche of ethylene production, given the abundant natural gas supplies. The U.S. should be in a strong position to export its ethylene-derivative products at a lower cost than incremental production elsewhere in the world. And I think, ultimately, the big question is will ethylene capacity be expanded to keep pace with increased NGL supplies here in the U.S.? And given the high ethane to ethylene spread that exists, we think ultimately that conversions and low-cost capacity increases will happen.
Slide 16 and 17 talk about the progress that we've made on the 2010 priorities for value creation. And you can see more and more of the boxes now have checkmarks. And so we're pleased with the progress that we're making there.
Slide 18 please. Why Williams is a winning investment? No change here. We think that we have the assets, the people, we have proven that we can execute crisply around our strategies. We are committed to financial discipline and believe that we're going to have very, very attractive results in the future.
Before we go to Q&A, I've got a few comments and Alan will as well. But I wanted to address questions about my decision to retire. There's no hidden intrigue or back story here. As Gwen and I were thinking about the next chapter in our life and having been with Williams for 26 years, 9 of those as CEO, we decided that -- again started talking about it over the summer and ultimately, decided that it made sense for us to retire at the end of 2010. And as you know, the requirements are such that once you make your final decision, you need to make it public in 4 or 5 days. So it's a decision that we're very excited about.
But the board was well prepared for this decision. We've had an active and comprehensive succession planning process in place. The board and I are confident in the team and confident in Alan Armstrong and believe that Alan will take the company to new heights. I've had a great opportunity to work with Alan, not only in his role as heading up our Midstream group, but I've worked closely with him back in the 1990s when I was running Midstream.
So -- and I don't want to get too carried away here, but the experience and culture here at Williams is very unique. And I've been proud to work here for the last 26 years. I truly believe the Williams' experience, the Williams' culture is a competitive advantage for us.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. First of all, Steve, I want to make sure that we acknowledge the accomplishments that Steve brought forward. If you think back to the very difficult and tenuous circumstances that Steve was handed and to where he brought us to today with a very str
componenttext:
Great. First of all, Steve, I want to make sure that we acknowledge the accomplishments that Steve brought forward. If you think back to the very difficult and tenuous circumstances that Steve was handed and to where he brought us to today with a very strong, very stable company with tremendous potential to create shareholder value from where we sit today. We have that potential in terms of financial resources. We've got extremely well-positioned assets in the markets they serve, and we've got tremendous organizational capabilities in terms of exporting resource play, both in our E&P group and in our Midstream group, and our pipes are well positioned to serve the change in the markets today associated with the resource plays. And certainly, as Steve mentioned, our culture with one of the most passionate and committed workforces in the business today leave me with a tremendous amount of optimism about where we can take this. And I just want to say a big thanks to Steve for giving us such a tremendous platform to take the company from today.
So we are in a very enviable position. We've got all the tools necessary to really accelerate shareholder value. We're going to be reviewing all alternatives. And I'm charged up and can assure you that with the great platform, the well-positioned assets and organizational capabilities that we have today, we will not be sitting still. I don't have any particular bias other than to assure ourselves that we are creating the most shareholder value that is enduring and allows our businesses to be the most successful they can be for the benefit of our investors.
And with that, I will turn this over to Q&A.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Craig Shere with Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Craig Shere with Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions here. Ralph, can you comment on how the commodity price assumptions underlying the guidance of 3% and 7% production throughout the next couple of years differs from the decision to write down some E&P properties? And at the current l
componenttext: A couple of questions here. Ralph, can you comment on how the commodity price assumptions underlying the guidance of 3% and 7% production throughout the next couple of years differs from the decision to write down some E&P properties? And at the current lower strips, is it reasonable to assume the gas production may be declining?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the goodwill impairment and the impairment of primarily the Barnett area is really is an accounting exercise that we work on, and it's basically there are several models there. It's the fair value model, and gross cash flows are discounted against t
componenttext: Well, the goodwill impairment and the impairment of primarily the Barnett area is really is an accounting exercise that we work on, and it's basically there are several models there. It's the fair value model, and gross cash flows are discounted against that. So as we look at that, for example, on the goodwill, the internal fair value was slightly less than the carrying value. And in that case, it caused an impairment of our goodwill, which was -- goodwill for us was associated with the 2001, almost a decade ago, acquisition of Barrett. And it wasn't cash out the door. It was really a deferred tax liability gross up, if you will. And that became our goodwill. And over the course of the last decade, as we looked at prices and all that, we really didn't have any opportunities for impairment and then with the forward price curve has gone down greater than 22% since the beginning of the year, that caused us to look at that and that caused that write-down. For the Barnett, it was simply just a factor of the fair value again versus the carrying value. Barnett forward prices have come down substantially and we have that impairment. That really doesn't have anything to do with go forward on where we're headed primarily in the Piceance and in the Marcellus, where most of our draw is in [ph]  And lesser extent, the powder. So those are just accounting exercises. If you look at it, you understand the value of what you're carrying versus the value of the fair value. And those were impaired from there. And I don't know if your last question is more about the industry or us. We know that the level of rigs that were -- which we did drop a substantial amount of rigs in our forecasts at the Barclays conference for '11 and '12. But we know that we believe our production is growing that much. I think the industry in general -- hopefully, at some time, we'll see our competitors put on more of a return hat and finish drilling for holding leases and finish drilling for holding JVs. And we'll see a more rational response to the gas prices and therefore, at that point, I would expect to see some of the gas supply to decline.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, what I'm trying to understand is the write-down based on forward strips, which are meaningfully below your midpoint guidance assumptions for the next 2 years? And if we incorporated that more conservative assumption, given the wide range of
componenttext: Well, I guess, what I'm trying to understand is the write-down based on forward strips, which are meaningfully below your midpoint guidance assumptions for the next 2 years? And if we incorporated that more conservative assumption, given the wide range of CapEx guidance for the next couple of years, is it reasonable to assume that we trend towards the lower end? This is what I'm trying to get at.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It is based on -- really, what happened is the strips, 20%, 25% is down about that. I mentioned greater than 20%. And I would say at this point, I would not trend towards the lower part. We feel confident that our drilling program -- as I think Steve ment
componenttext: It is based on -- really, what happened is the strips, 20%, 25% is down about that. I mentioned greater than 20%. And I would say at this point, I would not trend towards the lower part. We feel confident that our drilling program -- as I think Steve mentioned, the returns in the areas we're going to be drilling are anywhere from 17% to near 40%. We have cut our drilling programs substantially. But at this point, we feel that we'll be -- we don't give out exactly. We give a pretty wide range. I think most of you guys look at the middle part of that range, and that's kind of what you assume. That's generally where we try to come out. If prices would continue to come down, substantially, we always have the ability, as Steve said, to flex our portfolio down, our drilling program down and respond accordingly until prices come the right way.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And one other quick question, guys. I don't know if Don or Alan or Steve want to field this. But do I understand that the latest drop down to WPZ pre-tax, the WMB, may have been 7.5x EBITDA and after-tax maybe 6.5x? And does that seem a little low
componenttext: Great. And one other quick question, guys. I don't know if Don or Alan or Steve want to field this. But do I understand that the latest drop down to WPZ pre-tax, the WMB, may have been 7.5x EBITDA and after-tax maybe 6.5x? And does that seem a little low for a fee-based business? And how does that correlate to maybe future drop-downs and how you would envision pricing?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Don. I might just comment. You have to remember that Williams retains its GP interest. And with that, we get a substantial, you could call it a royalty. But we get a substantial profit participation in that asset despite the fact we dropped
componenttext: Craig, this is Don. I might just comment. You have to remember that Williams retains its GP interest. And with that, we get a substantial, you could call it a royalty. But we get a substantial profit participation in that asset despite the fact we dropped it down. So I think when you look at the GP interest on top of what we actually sold it for in terms of cash, I think you'd get a much higher valuation. In terms of what's left to drop down, we have a 25.5% interest in Gulfstream, which is eligible beginning kind of late first quarter. That's not guidance in terms of what we may do, but it would be eligible for drop-down kind of late first quarter. And beyond that, we really haven't earmarked any other assets.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Lasan Johong with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Lasan Johong with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me tackle -- this is Phil Wright. Let me tackle the Keystone Connector. It doesn't change anything with respect to what we're pursuing on that project and we continue to work with producers. As you know, the difficulty in achieving success on any of t
componenttext: Let me tackle -- this is Phil Wright. Let me tackle the Keystone Connector. It doesn't change anything with respect to what we're pursuing on that project and we continue to work with producers. As you know, the difficulty in achieving success on any of those large infrastructure projects is getting producers to a position where they have a clear enough vision of what their needs are going to be and what markets they want to try to serve sufficient to sign a precedent agreement that would produce enough security around the project that would have an investment profile attractive enough to proceed. And I think that chicken and egg problem persists. With respect to the McMullen lateral, I know Alan will have some probably from the Midstream perspective. But from the pipeline perspective, I can tell you that as more drilling is done out there and as the lenses of liquids-rich and oil-rich finds sort of move northward, we're seeing a higher level of interest in dry gas. But nonetheless, a very high level of interest in the McMullen lateral.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All I would add is that in terms of the -- first of fall, in terms of the Marcellus, it's -- we have a tremendous joint venture in our Atlas joint venture with Atlas, called Laurel Mountain. Outstanding growth alternatives coming out of that. And we've go
componenttext: All I would add is that in terms of the -- first of fall, in terms of the Marcellus, it's -- we have a tremendous joint venture in our Atlas joint venture with Atlas, called Laurel Mountain. Outstanding growth alternatives coming out of that. And we've got some exciting developments going on, on the north end of our Springville lateral. And so I don't feel like we're being left out in any way, shape or form. In fact, I would tell you, I think we probably have one of the strongest JVs in the Marcellus with -- from a Midstream perspective in terms of creating shareholder value going up there. So I'm very excited about that position. In terms of the Eagle Ford, the Markham plant, which is primarily positioned to serve the deep water Gulf of Mexico, does stand ready. It's got great liquids outlets and we just basically -- we want to make sure that we don't sell out that capacity too cheaply. There's not a whole lot of that existing capacity and great liquids market available. And we're going to make sure we get a premium for having that space available.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you asking a question there, Lasan? I'm sorry. I didn't...
componenttext: Are you asking a question there, Lasan? I'm sorry. I didn't...

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just say this. I think the integrated model, from my vantage point of being in the business and working with our E&P group and our gas pipe group, has absolutely created a lot of value. However, I think we certainly got to look to see that t
componenttext: Well, I would just say this. I think the integrated model, from my vantage point of being in the business and working with our E&P group and our gas pipe group, has absolutely created a lot of value. However, I think we certainly got to look to see that the markets fully appreciate the value. And that's certainly going to be an important consideration as we look at our alternatives going forward. So I think it's very early for you to conclude or anybody to conclude, really, where we stand on that because we will be looking at our alternatives. But I can assure you that everything is on the table and we will be not looking to sit still. So -- and we're looking to create rapidly accelerated shareholder value.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We -- this is Ralph. We had a previous forecast that had, I think, our growth was going to be 12% next year and then 16% the year after. And what we did is we essentially dropped about 10 rigs in 2011 and about, I think, it was 17 rigs in 2012's forecast.
componenttext: We -- this is Ralph. We had a previous forecast that had, I think, our growth was going to be 12% next year and then 16% the year after. And what we did is we essentially dropped about 10 rigs in 2011 and about, I think, it was 17 rigs in 2012's forecast. So we have the ability to go out. And that wouldn't all happen in 6 months, but we have the ability to rapidly ramp it back up if prices' signals would show that. And obviously, as Don would point out, that as our cash flows would grow, then that's where we try to live within our means. So I don't know how much would happen in 6 months. But I can tell you, a few months ago, we were planning on, with a different price tag, to have a substantial higher level of growth and we've dialed that back due to prices.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct. Yes, 3% in '11, about 7% in '12. And that's down from what was like 12% and 16%.
componenttext: Correct. Yes, 3% in '11, about 7% in '12. And that's down from what was like 12% and 16%.

componenttext: We could. At some point, we'd have to get the rigs and do all that. But we've been very successful and always been able to get good rigs, good crews. Our alliances with our vendors pays up very handsomely in time of ramp up and also helps when we ramp down.

componenttext: In 2011, we are now at -- we're projecting about where we are today in the Pineance. So we have 11 rigs running, 9 in the Valley and 2 in the Highlands. In the Barnett, we'll be down to one rig. And in the Marcellus, it's going to -- as Steve mentioned, I think it goes from 3 and ultimately ends up at 6 at the end of year. So on average, that in the Marcellus, it's more like, I hate to do this, but it's 4.75 rigs in the Marcellus. That's [indiscernible]  About 4 rigs from what we had planned earlier. And the Pineance is down 5 rigs and the Barnett is down 2 rigs.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And then again, just on E&P. It looks like you're evaluating on a lot expansion opportunities. You mentioned on one of the slides, I think Marcellus, Eagle Ford, even Bakken, how are you thinking about each of those opportuni
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And then again, just on E&P. It looks like you're evaluating on a lot expansion opportunities. You mentioned on one of the slides, I think Marcellus, Eagle Ford, even Bakken, how are you thinking about each of those opportunities? How do those fit in with your expertise, your footprint, et cetera?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think they fit in well. Obviously, the Eagle Ford and the Bakken bring a different look to our portfolio in a sense of liquids and to our condensate oil, which is we'd like to have that. But expertise-wise, we drilled hundreds and hundreds of horizontal
componenttext: I think they fit in well. Obviously, the Eagle Ford and the Bakken bring a different look to our portfolio in a sense of liquids and to our condensate oil, which is we'd like to have that. But expertise-wise, we drilled hundreds and hundreds of horizontal wells. We understand how to do that. So each of those areas work for us. So we continue to -- now we have a substantial position in the Marcellus of 100,000 acres. We'd like to continue to and evaluate opportunities there, and we are. Eagle Ford has had some great-looking opportunities out there. And obviously, there's other areas, such as the Bakken that we think they fits right in what our expertise is.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just -- since you issued the guidance 1 month, 1.5 month ago, gas prices are obviously lower and NGL prices are higher. I mean, are you thinking any differently now about capital allocation between E&P and Midstream? Or kind of h
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just -- since you issued the guidance 1 month, 1.5 month ago, gas prices are obviously lower and NGL prices are higher. I mean, are you thinking any differently now about capital allocation between E&P and Midstream? Or kind of how you're thinking about that going forward given where the prices have moved?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Don. We've asked our E&P business largely to live within its means. So to the extent it generates cash flows, we would expect they would likely consume those cash flows to reinvest in the business, again, with a bias towards liquids-rich areas, li
componenttext: This is Don. We've asked our E&P business largely to live within its means. So to the extent it generates cash flows, we would expect they would likely consume those cash flows to reinvest in the business, again, with a bias towards liquids-rich areas, like the Pineance. In fact, we do get a lot of liquids out of the Pineance. And I'd say that the WPZ Midstream and gas pipeline assets are well capitalized with a very low cost of capital. So we really don't see too much in the way of corporate capital moving back into that business for the foreseeable future.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Alan, actually, let me ask a question just on the Marcellus with respect to projects. With the curve coming down, the conversations with some-odd -- 40 some-odd producers, I guess, continuing, should we think about these as more incremental projects? Or do you still see sort of more a Laurel Mountain-ish type of potential, singular large scale projects that may come over the end zone some time in 2011, for instance?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we are pursuing those that gives us a large-scale position up there. And I've got pretty high hopes that we'll be able to deliver on something of similar nature to what we had in Laurel Mountain area. On top of that, however, there are a
componenttext: Well, certainly, we are pursuing those that gives us a large-scale position up there. And I've got pretty high hopes that we'll be able to deliver on something of similar nature to what we had in Laurel Mountain area. On top of that, however, there are a tremendous amount of those producers that we're talking to that infill into those assets that we're developing. And things like the Laurel Mountain JV and other alternatives up in the Northeast Pennsylvania area, we think are going to give us first mover advantage, allows to serve those remaining producers that we're talking to. So we're out there aggressively pursuing large anchor customers. And then we'll be in a position to better serve the balance of those customers.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Okay. So the back end of the curve coming down hasn't necessarily eliminated or drastically slowed down talks around these large-scale projects then? Just to confirm.

componenttext: Just paraphrasing what you said there, it doesn't sound like the back end of the curve coming down again because it's just a better marginal returns in the Marcellus. componenttext: Marcellus is well positioned to survive a very low gas price environment, and we're certainly not seeing any signs of people backing off in the most prime parts of the Marcellus.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Maybe if I could kind of go further north to Redwater. What do you think has to happen? The returns are there clearly. Given all the rhetoric we've seen, the Congress and the left on the environmental with the oil sands, there seems to be a l
componenttext: Fair enough. Maybe if I could kind of go further north to Redwater. What do you think has to happen? The returns are there clearly. Given all the rhetoric we've seen, the Congress and the left on the environmental with the oil sands, there seems to be a lot of driving factors that would continue to get you, guys, more business up there. What has to happen to kind of break that log jam?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just tell you that the process of negotiating, these are very long term. Obviously, those reserves are extremely long life. And so the contracts for them are fairly complex because they're meant to be very enduring. And so it just takes a wh
componenttext: Well, I would just tell you that the process of negotiating, these are very long term. Obviously, those reserves are extremely long life. And so the contracts for them are fairly complex because they're meant to be very enduring. And so it just takes a while to get through the contracting stage. But we are making very good progress on those fronts and look forward to making some announcements on that in not the very distant future. So don't assume lack of us announcing anything is lack of progress. We've got, actually, quite a bit of progress that's going on in the last quarter there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I appreciate those comments. And maybe one other question, if I could, for Ralph. Recognizing this is always a bit of a moving target. But in conjunction with the back end of the curve coming down as you guys are looking to potentially deploy more capital
componenttext: I appreciate those comments. And maybe one other question, if I could, for Ralph. Recognizing this is always a bit of a moving target. But in conjunction with the back end of the curve coming down as you guys are looking to potentially deploy more capital outside of the Rockies, what should we think about what you guys are using for sort of a long-term clearing price of oil and gas? I mean, should we be using the strip? Or if you guys were, say, for instance, to deploy $1 billion somewhere, what do we take as far as, "Boy, this is where they ultimately think gas and oil prices are going to trend out," call it 20-20 area, for instance?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have, obviously, several things we do. We have a point of view that at past 2012 we haven't published. We also have the market that we look at closely and we monitor what's going on in the market at all times. And then we run low cases, and we ru
componenttext: Well, we have, obviously, several things we do. We have a point of view that at past 2012 we haven't published. We also have the market that we look at closely and we monitor what's going on in the market at all times. And then we run low cases, and we run high cases, and we run stress cases. So I'm sorry, I can't give you an exact answer because we run a number of cases. We typically -- our point of view from time to time is pretty close to what the market is doing. That just happens, just the way it works out. But we look at so many different scenarios. It's hard to tell you exactly. But I can tell you, when we do look at all these, we severely stress test them to understand what it means in a low-price environment, both for the gas side and the oil side.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: And we'll move on to our next question from Jonathan Lefebvre with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just most of my questions have been touched. I just wanted to ask, with the announcement to sell the Midstream assets to PZ, I mean, it sounds like you want to deploy capital into more E&P assets. How do you weigh that against potentially doing a share re
componenttext: Just most of my questions have been touched. I just wanted to ask, with the announcement to sell the Midstream assets to PZ, I mean, it sounds like you want to deploy capital into more E&P assets. How do you weigh that against potentially doing a share repurchase?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Don. I would say, we're looking at capital redeployment, that very attractive after-tax rates of return using kind of the price scenario that Ralph laid out with we think a reasonable view of prices. And then also stress testing that and say, "How
componenttext: This is Don. I would say, we're looking at capital redeployment, that very attractive after-tax rates of return using kind of the price scenario that Ralph laid out with we think a reasonable view of prices. And then also stress testing that and say, "How bad could it be and would we still earn a return that was worthwhile." And if we have terrific opportunities and particularly, if we can do so on a way that broadens our footprint and perhaps also broadens our commodity mix, that would be interesting to us. In terms of stock buyback, I think our view to date has been in this very low-price environment. And with a very uncertain economy, we just really don't have much in the way of firepower to buy back stock without facing ratings downgrade. So we've -- as Alan said, all the options are on the table. We continue to look at all the options. But to date, we've not chosen to go down that path. But again, as Alan indicated, we continue to look at all the options and we'll do that whenever we make a decision on redeploying that capital.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But if I hear you correctly, the preference is for to do E&P acquisition versus share buybacks?
componenttext: But if I hear you correctly, the preference is for to do E&P acquisition versus share buybacks?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think -- I mean, clearly, we think that the share price is an attractive one. But we certainly don't want to face a downgrade in order to do that because that has broader implications. So we'll look at the options. We'll look at the potential consequenc
componenttext: I think -- I mean, clearly, we think that the share price is an attractive one. But we certainly don't want to face a downgrade in order to do that because that has broader implications. So we'll look at the options. We'll look at the potential consequences and benefits and make a decision that we think is in the best interest of the company and shareholders.

componenttext: Well, this is Ralph. I wouldn't comment at all on the imminent side of the world. But I can tell you that there -- as you probably know, there are a number of opportunities in all these basins. There always are. But there appears to be more than normal at this time. So there's just a lot of opportunities here. But as Don has said, Steve has said and Alan said, there are a number of things we take into account when we look at that. And so we evaluate continuously, my group and the rest of the groups here at Williams, opportunities. We see one we think creates value, we bring it to the table and we talk about it and we try to see if that's something we want to do. So there's just a lot out there right now, but they're typically is in this industry.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then looking at your guidance, I don't think you changed production guidance for this year, which would sort of imply pretty significant sequential growth from the fourth quarter to the third quarter. 1, am I accurate in looking at it that way a
componenttext: Okay. And then looking at your guidance, I don't think you changed production guidance for this year, which would sort of imply pretty significant sequential growth from the fourth quarter to the third quarter. 1, am I accurate in looking at it that way and I guess, 2, what would be driving that?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just the -- it's really the -- yes, you are accurate in looking at it that way. It's just we've arrested the decline that we had. When you're coming off, for example, 28 rigs in the Piceance and you're going down to what we went down to as 10 a
componenttext: Well, it's just the -- it's really the -- yes, you are accurate in looking at it that way. It's just we've arrested the decline that we had. When you're coming off, for example, 28 rigs in the Piceance and you're going down to what we went down to as 10 and now we're at 12. That's a huge decline that you overcome when you just look at the way these tight sand wells come on and or any kind of wells that we drill now. So we've overcome that decline for the number of rigs that we dropped. And now that we've done that, the volumes are starting to tweak back up. You see we had a 2% growth, I believe, company-wide, sequentially in the third quarter versus second quarter. I think Piceance itself is up 5%. So the big driver will be the Piceance. And then also, we have the new basin where we started to get a little traction on in the Marcellus. But you are seeing it correctly that we have arrested the decline. We're actually growing again, and we expect a decent growth in the fourth quarter.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my final question is, so you updated guidance from a month ago and growth CapEx went up at WPZ. And obviously, some of that has to do with this recent drop. Is there anything else that was added in the past month? Or is it at all because of
componenttext: Okay. And then my final question is, so you updated guidance from a month ago and growth CapEx went up at WPZ. And obviously, some of that has to do with this recent drop. Is there anything else that was added in the past month? Or is it at all because of the new assets coming in?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We do have some -- there is some additional capital in there from the Midstream side associated with the more rapid expansion of our Laurel Mountain system. And so that's one of the primary drivers of additional capital on there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alan, on the liquids volumes for the third quarter, they were down sequentially versus the second quarter. Can you comment on any outages and what was going on there? Maybe methane rejection?
componenttext: Alan, on the liquids volumes for the third quarter, they were down sequentially versus the second quarter. Can you comment on any outages and what was going on there? Maybe methane rejection?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Really, there was 2 primary issues there that did affect it. And you are right, it's actually fairly substantial reduction in our equity gallons. First of all, in the Mobile Bay area, we had Exxon, who is the big producer in to Mobile Bay, had some
componenttext: Sure. Really, there was 2 primary issues there that did affect it. And you are right, it's actually fairly substantial reduction in our equity gallons. First of all, in the Mobile Bay area, we had Exxon, who is the big producer in to Mobile Bay, had some outages on one of their offshore pipelines, completely unrelated to the drilling moratorium that reduced input coming into the plant substantially. In addition to that, though, we also -- the way those contracts work, they have rights to take their liquids for a certain number of months out of the year. And it just so happened that 2 of those -- that piled up, their option piled up in this quarter. It's actually our election. And so with their outage, we elected to give them the liquids in that period where there was an outage. So that was by far the largest. And then out West, we had reduction related to a force majeure that we got from ONEOK at their Bushton fractionator. And that backed up all of our plants in the West. They had some difficulties maintaining with the volumes ramping up so rapidly, coming out of the West, they've had some difficulty keeping our infrastructure out in front of that. And that resulted in a force majeure that did impact our western volumes. So all in all, we are really well positioned right now with our Echo plant being now up, which just really got spinning here in -- towards the end of September. And we've gotten some of the line problems resolved that we had on the Perdido tie-in, which were affecting our Markham volumes as well. So going into the fourth quarter here, we are really well positioned to get back on track on our liquids production and grow that pretty rapidly.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. On the E&P side, Ralph, is there any point in time when you look at price that you maybe look at shutting in production?
componenttext: Okay, great. On the E&P side, Ralph, is there any point in time when you look at price that you maybe look at shutting in production?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've done that a little bit last year and then primarily it was in the Powder. And so we look at it from time to time. But we're, at this point, we're not contemplating any of that. And we're about 56%, 60% hedged. We have a number of things that go into
componenttext: We've done that a little bit last year and then primarily it was in the Powder. And so we look at it from time to time. But we're, at this point, we're not contemplating any of that. And we're about 56%, 60% hedged. We have a number of things that go into that. If you're shutting in, that complicate that. So it needs to be a more than a -- or it would need  to be for a substantial period of time. We don't see a reason to do that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. And then, as you look at this kind of more liquids-rich opportunities, is there -- do you think that given all the transactions that are taking place, the prices are too high? Or do you think they're still reasonable?
componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then, as you look at this kind of more liquids-rich opportunities, is there -- do you think that given all the transactions that are taking place, the prices are too high? Or do you think they're still reasonable?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it depends on where you're looking and if you're in the sweet spots or not. But we think and generally, we think we know what the markets -- where the market is in our area of interest. We feel we know what it takes to win in certain areas, so to an
componenttext: Well, it depends on where you're looking and if you're in the sweet spots or not. But we think and generally, we think we know what the markets -- where the market is in our area of interest. We feel we know what it takes to win in certain areas, so to an extent, we find something we think from a technical standpoint that hits our sweet spot, then I think that's when we look to try to move something forward. So, so many transactions are out there. It's hard to say which ones are good or bad. But we look at it first from the technical standpoint. If our exploration team likes it, our engineer likes it, it hits and we evaluate it as what we call the sweet spot, then that's something we'll be more aggressive at looking than other fringe areas.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then with the write down that you guys took, is there going to be any impact to DD&A or reserves?
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then with the write down that you guys took, is there going to be any impact to DD&A or reserves?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't -- the reserves report will come out at the end of the year. We're doing other reserves, are based on different things. The reserves are basically on the average of the 12 -- first month prices for 12 months. And the gas prices this year are high
componenttext: We don't -- the reserves report will come out at the end of the year. We're doing other reserves, are based on different things. The reserves are basically on the average of the 12 -- first month prices for 12 months. And the gas prices this year are higher than last year, if you average that in. So there's not really impact on reserves. On DD&A, yes, we do see an impact to our DD&A. It's probably going to go down about $0.10 to $0.15 company wide for 2011 and about $0.10 again in 2012. That has been baked into the guidance. Basically, as you see the previous guidance and we, at that time, we own what we call the Piceance gathering assets, we also call that bar GAP. We own those. They were previously in our guidance. Now it's out of our guidance, but we did get some DD&A pickup on the other side. So in general, you see our guidance didn't really change. They kind of offset each other.

componenttext: Okay. Got you. componenttext: Well, the activity around us -- the other operators around us, said they've had great successes there. So we bought into those concessions. We're excited that in one of them, we'll start drilling next year, and the other one we're still doing seismic on. But the operators in that area have done very, very well. So we think it's time to make sure everybody  understands that we have interest in those areas.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just -- most of my questions have actually been answered at this point. But Ralph, I know it's still very early in the Marcellus for you guys but you've outlined some particular areas in your presentation. Can you just talk about well results to date? I k
componenttext: Just -- most of my questions have actually been answered at this point. But Ralph, I know it's still very early in the Marcellus for you guys but you've outlined some particular areas in your presentation. Can you just talk about well results to date? I know you referenced in the slides some of your best wells being the Westmoreland County. Can you just kind of talk about that from a bigger picture standpoint?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the Westmoreland County area -- and again, we took over operations just a few months ago. But what we're seeing in our first handful for several wells there is that 90-day flows and some of the areas are still above or at the $3.5 million a day type
componenttext: Yes, the Westmoreland County area -- and again, we took over operations just a few months ago. But what we're seeing in our first handful for several wells there is that 90-day flows and some of the areas are still above or at the $3.5 million a day type flows. So that's -- we're impressed with that. We like that. So we're just still learning, understanding but we like all of the areas we're in. And obviously, we're excited to do a lot more in Susquehanna County. We're only running one rig up there now and obviously, we have some completions that we're backing up on because of the delay in the Laser pipeline. But in general, all of Clearfield, Westmoreland and Centre Counties are doing very well. Westmoreland is doing slightly better. And I think Susquehanna, as you know, will do much better than any of those once we get there. So we're excited that we brought in a fit for purpose Patterson [ph] rig. We brought in a rig from H&P [ph], from the Rockies. So we're happy to have at least 2 of those rigs that are fit for purpose. We've contracted for some more. And again, it's just kind of like what we see -- what happened in the Piceance, when you get the right crews, the right equipment and get the opportunity to move it in to a more of a scale operation. We think the efficiencies will come like we've seen in the Piceance.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any test rates on the Susquehanna wells?
componenttext: Any test rates on the Susquehanna wells?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not from us. But we're intermixed with, for example, Cabot and others. And you've seen their results, and we're right in the middle of all of that. So we're anxious to have that when that comes on. And then hopefully, Laser could come on in mid next year.
componenttext: Not from us. But we're intermixed with, for example, Cabot and others. And you've seen their results, and we're right in the middle of all of that. So we're anxious to have that when that comes on. And then hopefully, Laser could come on in mid next year. And so we'll start completing before that and have some good results for you.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And given the delays that you've seen with Laser and then your pullback in capital, what's your kind of expected timeframe now to achieve this goal of the Marcellus being the second largest producing basin for you guys?
componenttext: Okay. And given the delays that you've seen with Laser and then your pullback in capital, what's your kind of expected timeframe now to achieve this goal of the Marcellus being the second largest producing basin for you guys?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we said that would happen by I think within this when we gave our kind of longer term forecast, which I think went through 2015. And based on the 4 rigs averaging and the Marcellus going up to in 2012, we currently have a buildup to 10 rigs and then
componenttext: Well, we said that would happen by I think within this when we gave our kind of longer term forecast, which I think went through 2015. And based on the 4 rigs averaging and the Marcellus going up to in 2012, we currently have a buildup to 10 rigs and then it goes up a little more after that. We still can easily make that in the next 4 years or so.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next 4 years. Okay. And then finally, just from an integrated model standpoint, can that -- how can that help you, I guess, alleviate these delays you're seeing in the Marcellus from an infrastructure standpoint?
componenttext: Next 4 years. Okay. And then finally, just from an integrated model standpoint, can that -- how can that help you, I guess, alleviate these delays you're seeing in the Marcellus from an infrastructure standpoint?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, at this time, the only delay we really have is with Laser. And we've got our other facilities in what we call the Washanna compressor station and the gathering facilities all in the other areas and Clearfield County and Westmoreland, they're in good
componenttext: Well, at this time, the only delay we really have is with Laser. And we've got our other facilities in what we call the Washanna compressor station and the gathering facilities all in the other areas and Clearfield County and Westmoreland, they're in good shape. The Laser is not a part of us or our Midstream group, so that doesn't help us in that particular area. However, as you know, Laurel Mountain's got the really more of the outlet to the south that's out there. And there is, as L&M continues to grow and expand, maybe there's opportunities in the future, who knows, for consolidations, and that would be great if L&M would be out there being the consolidator and being able to take over some of those things.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But you feel like you're pretty set in terms of your growing production or you're anticipating growing production in a pretty meaningful way here in the Marcellus. So you feel like you're pretty set from an infrastructure standpoint over the next couple o
componenttext: But you feel like you're pretty set in terms of your growing production or you're anticipating growing production in a pretty meaningful way here in the Marcellus. So you feel like you're pretty set from an infrastructure standpoint over the next couple of years?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think we will be, yes.
componenttext: We think we will be, yes.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Smith with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Smith with Raymond James.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: What do you think your kind of rates of return right now are in the Piceance Valley and the Highlands on the drill bed?
componenttext: What do you think your kind of rates of return right now are in the Piceance Valley and the Highlands on the drill bed?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're showing -- in the Piceance Valley, we believe our returns are, I'll just give you a range, 35% to 40%. And in the Highlands, they're more mid, upper teens, so 17%, 18% type of returns. And the Highlands next year all we're going to drill at this poi
componenttext: We're showing -- in the Piceance Valley, we believe our returns are, I'll just give you a range, 35% to 40%. And in the Highlands, they're more mid, upper teens, so 17%, 18% type of returns. And the Highlands next year all we're going to drill at this point will be in Ryan Gulch area. Obviously, we pulled that capital. So those returns are primarily focused in the Ryan Gulch. Although that still is kind of a combination what we'd call Ryan Gulch Trail Ridge well. So Ryan Gulch will have a slightly higher net. The number I gave you on the upper teens is really kind of a hybrid of the Trail Ridge and Ryan Gulch.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so are you going be having enough activity right now in the Highlands to keep production flat and then slightly grow it in the Valley? Is that the right way to look at it?
componenttext: Okay. And so are you going be having enough activity right now in the Highlands to keep production flat and then slightly grow it in the Valley? Is that the right way to look at it?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the Valley will clearly grow. And the Highlands has been growing. The Highlands will -- it'll be a challenge to keep it flat. But it seems we probably would need to -- the 2 rigs, it will be tight. We may need to -- we may decline in the Highlands s
componenttext: Well, the Valley will clearly grow. And the Highlands has been growing. The Highlands will -- it'll be a challenge to keep it flat. But it seems we probably would need to -- the 2 rigs, it will be tight. We may need to -- we may decline in the Highlands some.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And outside the Marcellus, is there any other areas you're expecting to actually grow production? Or to grow production, sorry?
componenttext: Okay. And outside the Marcellus, is there any other areas you're expecting to actually grow production? Or to grow production, sorry?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Production, generally, will be flat in the San Juan. It'll be slightly declining in the Barnett. We have a number of completions we're backed up on in the Barnett that will keep that sort of remain -- it will go down, but it won't go down by as much you t
componenttext: Production, generally, will be flat in the San Juan. It'll be slightly declining in the Barnett. We have a number of completions we're backed up on in the Barnett that will keep that sort of remain -- it will go down, but it won't go down by as much you think by dropping to one rig.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are we still seeing takeaway activities backed up in the Barnett? Or is that just kind of timing of when you decide to do the projects?
componenttext: Are we still seeing takeaway activities backed up in the Barnett? Or is that just kind of timing of when you decide to do the projects?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really Barnett is just much more of a permitting side of the world on -- basically which is somewhat strange with the compression facilities and on water facilities. It's not the takeaway capacity for us as much as it is on just permits in some of the are
componenttext: Really Barnett is just much more of a permitting side of the world on -- basically which is somewhat strange with the compression facilities and on water facilities. It's not the takeaway capacity for us as much as it is on just permits in some of the areas we're operating on, on trying to what we think is the best practice, build centralized water facilities and larger compressor areas just to be more efficient.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Yves Siegel with CrÃ©dit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Yves Siegel with CrÃ©dit Suisse.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just some quick follow-up questions. One, on the E&P side, do you think of asset dispositions at all? I mean does it make sense to maybe exit the Barnett Shale and redeploy cash flow elsewhere?
componenttext: Just some quick follow-up questions. One, on the E&P side, do you think of asset dispositions at all? I mean does it make sense to maybe exit the Barnett Shale and redeploy cash flow elsewhere?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we look at all options like that, and that is an option that's out there. It depends on what's going on in the marketplace. But the Barnett has been frustrating simply from a standpoint of -- a lot of what we saw was just a complete delay in
componenttext: Yes, I think we look at all options like that, and that is an option that's out there. It depends on what's going on in the marketplace. But the Barnett has been frustrating simply from a standpoint of -- a lot of what we saw was just a complete delay in the opportunity to get the facilities we needed to. It wasn't the drilling permits. It's just actually getting the facilities done to get our gas to market. And that caused a chain link or a chain reaction in losing value.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you have discretion in terms of the timing of the write-down? Could you have waited until you reported year end to do that? Or was it something that you were required to do at this time?
componenttext: Did you have discretion in terms of the timing of the write-down? Could you have waited until you reported year end to do that? Or was it something that you were required to do at this time?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's something we're -- yes, we're required to do. They're really -- and in this aspect, it's something we actually look at all the time. And then in the last year's Q, we basically talked about that there are certain triggers we were looking at, on
componenttext: Well, it's something we're -- yes, we're required to do. They're really -- and in this aspect, it's something we actually look at all the time. And then in the last year's Q, we basically talked about that there are certain triggers we were looking at, one would be at the forward market price, and again, this is a forward market price, like 2025 would have a decline by more than 20%. We would have to take a look at this, and it did. But we look at it every quarter anyway. But for this particular quarter, the forward market price is down substantially. And it's just an automatic check. There's no -- we don't have the opportunity to pick when we want to do that.
