headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that was just off-the-wall question. And then the last question is when you look at potential growth CapEx, it looks like there's a real big chunk of opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico. Could you elaborate on how you think about that going forward?
componenttext: Okay, that was just off-the-wall question. And then the last question is when you look at potential growth CapEx, it looks like there's a real big chunk of opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico. Could you elaborate on how you think about that going forward?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. A lot of continued opportunity out there. The Canyon area continues to be a very active area and certainly underserved from an infrastructure standpoint. And we think we're very well positioned to capture some of that business out there. And as well
componenttext: Sure. A lot of continued opportunity out there. The Canyon area continues to be a very active area and certainly underserved from an infrastructure standpoint. And we think we're very well positioned to capture some of that business out there. And as well, continuing to grow the infrastructure out of the Eastern Gulf area out of our Devil's Tower facility as well. So we continue to see a lot of opportunity out there. And our GulfStar generic platform, basically, that is now well designed and really ready to be deployed. We think can add a tremendous amount of value to producers out there. And we're continuing to have a lot of interest in that. I think all that has to really change out there. And I'm not predicting how rapidly this will change, but I do think what's going to be required is for the producers to gain confidence that even though the moratorium is lifted, that permits will actually be processed in a timely basis and in a reasonable fashion. And I think everybody's waiting to see on that front. But if it does happen, then there is tremendous resource out there, and it's going to need a lot of infrastructure, and we're very well positioned to serve that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just from the realization of cash flow. Is that a long lead time? Would you be able to do it incrementally? Or would there be a big lag between dollars invested and at the start of incremental cash?
componenttext: And just from the realization of cash flow. Is that a long lead time? Would you be able to do it incrementally? Or would there be a big lag between dollars invested and at the start of incremental cash?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think generally from the time that we really start investing dollars on many of those projects to the time we've got cash flow is about -- the smaller projects would maybe, be 1.5 years and the longer projects would be 3 years. So to answer your qu
componenttext: Yes, I think generally from the time that we really start investing dollars on many of those projects to the time we've got cash flow is about -- the smaller projects would maybe, be 1.5 years and the longer projects would be 3 years. So to answer your question is yes, in terms of that capital, those large capital dollars being deployed. However, as you know, where we've got infrastructure already there and production gets tied into that, that comes on pretty rapidly for us. And so there's a mix of that. But in terms of the capital, those large chunks of capital that you see in our potential pie there, most of that would be probably in the 2.5-year range from the time we would be investing heavily to the time we would see cash flows come back.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Don. On your impairment question, I just remind everyone that in 2008, 2009, many, many companies across the industry took very large write-downs. We did not. So while we took the write-down this quarter, we haven't had any large write-downs back
componenttext: This is Don. On your impairment question, I just remind everyone that in 2008, 2009, many, many companies across the industry took very large write-downs. We did not. So while we took the write-down this quarter, we haven't had any large write-downs back in the '08, '09 period when many, many other write-downs were taken.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, it's Paul [ph] of the 20 peers that we tracked. I believe they took write-downs of approximately $52 billion over those 2 years.
componenttext: Yes, Don, it's Paul [ph] of the 20 peers that we tracked. I believe they took write-downs of approximately $52 billion over those 2 years.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks for tuning in. We're excited about the future. Our best-of-class assets, the strong balance sheet, significant inventory of growth opportunities and talented and dedicated workforce, we think, will translate into significant shareholder value
componenttext: Well, thanks for tuning in. We're excited about the future. Our best-of-class assets, the strong balance sheet, significant inventory of growth opportunities and talented and dedicated workforce, we think, will translate into significant shareholder value growth in the future. So thank you very much. Bye.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation.
